description: This place had a great breakfast chorizo burrito. It was kind of expense for the size of the burrito you got but it was overall a good place. The staff was friendly and even though it was busy, they kept up pretty well.
author: Angel R.

description:
Combo of a crunchy taco with ground beef and a carne asada enchilada.

The meat was cold and grisly and the salsa bar didn't look fresh. In fact it looked watery and recycled.

The rice was good, but the beans were plain and the enchilada tasted like a microwave TV dinner.

The taco was a disappointment, hard and greasy.

Definitely agree with the mid two to three star reviews here.
author: Jack R.

description: Just had a bean, cheese & rice burrito. The best way to tell if the food will be good or not. Well, rice had a commercial flavor, lousy taste. Beans had no flavor tasted flat, not favorable. Beans were at a fast boil, instead of simmering, added to much water while cooking. Charged $6.25 and no cheese. Not authentic mexican.
author: Black V.

description: First time at Caramba Mexican Food today. It's located near the 2nd and Stevenson Muni stop and Flower Power dispensary. My colleagues have eaten here before and had good things to say, so I tried it. My experience was not as positive as theirs. So, when I entered the establishment, I was a bit confused about the prices because on the window there is a menu with all whited out prices. When I got it in, its like most Mexican food establishments where you place your order, they prepare it in front of you and you pay at the end. I ordered a Regular Shrimp Burrito on a spinach wrap and I must say, "I was not impressed." For $11.92 I expect that my burrito to be wrapped tightly. When I unwrapped it from the foil, it basically unrolled and as most people know, it's almost impossible to re-roll "correctly!" The shrimp was not seasoned and I had to remind the woman at the counter to give me tortilla chips like she did everyone else. Overall the burrito was edible, but, I'm disappointed I spent roughly $12 on something that wasn't t better than chipotle. I hope you have a better experience than I did.
author: Rhett B.

description: Stopped here to grab a breakfast burrito on the run. It was fast and hit and spot.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Would highly recommend this place if you want quality Mexican food! I've always passed Caramba on my way to work from Market St, but one day I ordered a breakfast burrito from this place and was blown away at how good it was!

Unlike the other breakfast burrito places in the area, Caramba's burritos are super flavorful and also very affordable - they come out to like $5.00 per burrito.

Further, they accept orders over the phone so you don't have to ever wait there. I know i'll be a repeat customer here when I'm craving a breakfast burrito in the morning.
author: James D.

description:
My coworkers recommended this place to me, especially knowing I was a vegetarian. So I came here for a veggie burrito to-go on a Thursday afternoon after prime-time lunch hours. There were only a few people in line, so I had the time to figure out exactly what I wanted.

The staff was extremely patient and helpful while I still contemplated my choices (I didn't use my time wisely) but I ended up making a beautiful vegetarian burrito. It was hella cheap (like under $7), especially for SF prices.

My food was good, but not mind-blowing. I think my coworkers had overhyped the food. The beans were a little dry, the veggies were good, the tortilla was a bit soggy from the sour cream. Overall, good place for lunch. It's a little heavy (don't wanna fall into a food coma) but worth it if there's a small line.
author: Rahul R.

description: This is a nice Mexican restaurant near my office. They have a wide range of options for food and meats. My personal favorite is the Super Burrito with Carnitas. The place can get crowded during lunch, but the line moves pretty quickly, much faster than Chipotle.
author: Wyatt S.

description: Their soft tacos are legit. size is good and they have 4-5 different kinds salsa. No free chips. This is my 2nd favourite Mexican restaurant in the financial district. First being Tropiseuno.
author: Madhu J.

description:
Pretty decent Taqueria.  Actually the one Taqueria I know of in the Financial district.

Can get pretty busy during lunch hour.  Every thing is assembled on a buffet hot line.  

Not really fresh but good.
author: jason v.

description:
I randomly picked Caramba for lunch a couple of days ago as I was in the mood for Mexican food and wanted something close by my place of work. At the peak lunch hour the place was packed and there was a big line, both of which is expected in FiDi so I joined the end.

In most places the line moves fast, but not the case here. The place felt very loud mostly because the people behind the counter were shouting things to each other. When my turn came I saw a big white sheet of paper calling my name - It had Chicken Chimichanga ($8.99) written on top so I went with that. It was a little bit of a challenge to let the server know that would like the sour cream and guacamole but I'm used to that by now. Again after ordering it was a pretty long wait or at-least it felt like a pretty long wait to get my order to-go. I timed it - from the time I entered to the time I left it was 25 minutes of standing in line and then waiting for the order, which was a whole 10 minutes above my acceptable threshold for lunch at FiDi.

Let's come to the food. I got a decent sized container with a lot of food. The Chimichanga was big enough that even a hearty eater like me would have some left-overs. Here's the catch it was a soggy, rubbery, chewy piece of crap. Obviously this was not made to order but was fried probably early morning and then had been sitting out so that it could be dished out to idiots like me. I should stop doing this to myself i.e. ordering fried food from essentially what are seam table operations. I have to report that the chicken in the Chimichanga was not dry and if I'd got it in a wet burrito I would have probably praised it. Even the rice was not the typical over steamed Mexican rice that you get at Taqueria's. So after discarding the outer soggy tortilla the rest of the contents were very eatable.

Price wise it was cheap for FiDi. Overall looking at the time it took for the order, the quality of what I got and the distance from my place of work, I'm not really inclined to return here in a hurry. The only Mexican place worth going to in FiDi in my opinion is Tropisueño but that is for another review.
author: Ahmad J.

description: A great place for handmade breakfast burritos. I get mine with avocado and without a tortilla to make them more keto-friendly. The ladies behind the counter are always friendly and smiling. They have a salsa bar and their "salsa hot" is just hot enough to hurt-so-good while keeping you coming back for more.
author: Tim K.

description: Best breakfast burrito place in the city!!!! I would go here every Friday morning with my coworker and grab a burrito before the day started. You can call it in and then pick it up too. But the staff is extremely nice and the price is amazing. They're on the smaller side too which I like but you can always add extras into it.
author: Melissa S.

description: Had the regular shrimp burrito with pinto beans & mild salsa.  It was both filling and tasty.  Will go back for the other options.
author: Jim I.

description: Solid, authentic burrito spot on the FiDi/SoMa border. I've had both breakfast and lunch many times. Consistency is key in my eyes, and they always deliver quality ingredients, properly marinated meats, a nice selection of flavorful tortillas you wouldn't normally suspect at this type of joint (spinach, etc.) and they are liberal with portions. Cost is unbeatable, especially for the area. Tasty, freshly made salsas available in a "salsa bar" off to the side of the register. Amazingly friendly staff, always the same women which is a good indication of how they run their business. It's great they are open so early on weekdays. My only complaint is that they aren't open later or on the weekends, as I live nearby and would love the convenience and to be able to take guests from out of town here.
author: Ashley C.

description: I like the taste of their breakfast burritos but the workers don't have any sense of basic sanitation. The cashier just handled dirty money, touched screens of the iPad and went directly to roll your burritos. Really? Can you wash your hands first or put on gloves?
author: Bonnie W.

description: What is nice about this place is that it is authentic. It is not easy to find real Sopes and they have them. This place is not the cleanest but they do move quickly. Quality and price are good, great for a decent lunch in the City.
author: Ken A.

description:
This place is slightly pricey for a hole in the wall Mexican food stop, but the restaurant definitely has an air of authenticity. I appreciated that the cashier honored my Yelp check in even though my purchase was 8.50 after tax and tip rather than before. After debating between the shrimp (9.99) and the grilled chicken (6.99), I ordered a grilled chicken burrito with black beans, rice, and cheese. 

The service was friendly, the restaurant was clean, and the salsa bar was flavorful and well stocked. The green salsa in particular was delicious. My burrito, however, was extremely dry. The chicken was well cooked but not quite juicy, and the beans weren't liquid enough to add flavor to the rice. I think the proportion of rice to everything else was too high, maybe next time I'd ask for less rice and more beans.
author: Mili P.

description:
Not going to say much except that I went to Caramba for lunch on a Tuesday afternoon and was left bitterly disappointed. I ordered the Chicken Torta and this was the driest Torta I've ever had in my entire life. 

Still giving it a 2 star since I haven't tried the Burrito or the Chimichanga yet, and I'll come back and update my review if they change my opinion.
author: Gaurav K.

description:
It's not something I enjoy, giving a bad review. I fully understand the effect that numerous bad reviews can have on a business and I only hope the owners/management can improve their establishment, over time, with constructive criticism.

The employees I encountered where all very friendly and quick to serve. 

Music matters. I know it's not free but neither is electricity, it's a must. Turn on the radio. Even the detritus known as KOIT is better than dead silence.

The menu is easy to read and makes ordering very quick and painless. Thank you.

The Steak quesadilla was my choice for the day and because I was living large I upped the ante and indulged in a side (small portion cup) of, "sour cream." This stuff was so cut it didn't even taste sour and had the consistency of La Victoria Green Mild Salsa. What a nightmare. If I was to guess, it tasted like it was mixed with heavy cream. I didn't even care to ask the price when she asked to add it on so had I been charged a $1 I'd have been none the wiser. Maybe I was. For two table spoons, at the most, for a buck you'd turn a darn good profit for the best sour cream San Francisco has to offer but instead I was given something even Taco Bell couldn't get away with. I must assume they sell it to you at the counter as there isn't enough to put into your quesadilla and still taste it.

Talking about taste one thing that must be present is oil and fat. Let's be honest here friends, we all very well understand that a quesadilla must drip a little. There's got to be juice. No juice. No flavor. When I was given my tiny portion cup of, "sour cream" I was also given two small napkins. I thought to my self, "that isn't going to cut it!" But you know what? I didn't even touch my second napkin because this poor excuse for a meal didn't drip once. Check out my plate. Pathetic.

Personal rant: The sign posted behind the counter, facing the customers, stating, "No cell phones for employees," yells out to me that management is disengaged from their staff. I get that people shouldn't be on their phones while getting paid. In fact, I fully support it but put it somewhere else so customers don't have to look at it. I wouldn't take points off for this but it makes me not want to stick around. It doesn't sound like a fun place to work. And it's super quiet, like a library on Sunday morning.

Next!
author: Justin S.

description: Best Bfast Burritos you can get in Soma and Fidi!
author: Rj D.

description:
I have been here once for myself and the other 3 times to order a large order of breakfast burritos for my office, and every time there is a long wait AFTER I have placed my order. 

Although my manager orders our 40 burritos well in advance, a couple hours before needing to be picked up, we still have to wait about 20-30 minutes before they finish them completely.

When I had gone just by myself and ordered right then and there, I also waitied about 10-20 minutes because there were people ahead of me. 

The food itself as always been good! I can usually eat 2.
author: Michael T.

description: Super simple place with delicious food. I went with a friend for breakfast, I had the chorizo & egg burrito sandwich. It was very good, it is a bit small for those who wake up with a big appetite. You can add riz or potatoes to it. That must fill you in.
author: Naoufel T.

description:
Let's just say you happen to have a night where you're "over served"....aka, hungover. 

You make it into work but the hunger from your tummy is next level. The work kitchen might have some staples but you NEED a breakfast burrito. 

Caramba is your jam in this situation. They make PERFECT breakfast burritos that will put you in a good place post drinking. Pair them with an Advil and coconut water and your good to go by 10am. 

If you're looking to make friends at work bring Caramba a list of what your coworkers want and they will even write the people's names on the burritos! 

Thank you Caramba, you have been bringing me back to life since 2010.
author: Alison C.

description: I give it 3 stars because the food was delicious. I went into this place with high hopes since my co-workers kept recommending caramba to me because of their authentic mexican food. Although the food was great, the women that "helped" me out were so busy chatting up amongst themselves they ended up messing up my order. I asked for no sour cream many times and it seemed like they were ignoring me. I get my burrito and, you guessed it! sour cream all over the burrito. I didn't have time to wait for another so I left with the incorrect order.
author: Frank L.

description:
$3 - $5 authentic breakfast burritos in the financial district! Is there much more that needs to be said??

Pro Tip: Get in there before 8am or the line will be out of control. However, I'm not above waiting in a line out the door for these burrito babies.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Quick speedy service and average prices (~$10 for a burrito.) convenient location in soma but inconveniently placed menu. 

Call me old fashioned, but I think tortilla chips should never cost extra. 

It'll do if you need a quick lunch. I had the regular chicken burrito and it wasn't too dry or soggy, and definitely was heavy on onions. Good, but it's not even close competition to being the best burrito in the city.
author: Trevor B.

description: Yum! Right around the corner from my office and the perfect place for a quick, basically homemade breakfast. Super sweet staff. No frills. Cheap and fast.
author: Alit E.

description:
Hiiii!!

I love this place! It's open for breakfast, lunch and dinner and is pretty much the go to for my entire office.  The food is delicious, they have a groovy salsa bar, and inexpensive.  The quality is great, portions huge and staff very friendly, they always remember your order and are super fast.  

I guess a couple of things stands out about Caramba, you can get everything and the food is damn tasty.  So you can order everything from a torts to a chile relleno to a burrito (mojado) here and it is good.  Everything is cooked to order and from cold to hot and so is fresh tasting.

The staff are also friendly, fast, efficient and experienced.  Again, prices are very reasonable for the FIDi.

Thanks for reviewing, LET'S EAT!!
author: Brandon E.

description:
Amazing fast service ; friendly staff ; not your typical SOMA burrito spot. 

Try their Carnitas !! muy bueno
author: Marcus K.

description: i ate a super chicken burrito here this week.  beans, rice, salsa, cheese, guacamole and tortilla.  i'm come here often before.  it's good, a bit pricey but so is everything in the area.  salsa always taste good, and you have a selection of different kind.  i havent tried anything except for the chicken burritos and chips.
author: Richard M.

description:
Caramba always hits the spot! 2 blocks away from my work and the line goes by quick. So far haven't had issues with quality; they have been consistent with their food which is great for a quick go-to lunch spot during the work week.

One bad thing I can see some folks have issues with is their line; there's no specific order. If the lady behind the counter 2 people ahead of you becomes free and youre the next available person, you jump ahead 2 people. So the whole thing can get confusing if you don't pay attention. 

Overall, delicious.
author: Robbie P.

description:
We just beat the crowd.  I think it was just about noon.  A bit overwhelmed at the options.  But I was with a friend who liked the place and I just followed her lead.
She had a special. I had the shrimp... Something's. I think the special was better. It was a steak thing. But lots of veggies with my shrimp 
It was good. If you're in the neighborhood it's worth popping in. Good prices and friendly folks. Lots of drinks to choose. Huh. Not sure why that stands out but it does.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Amazing Food! Amazing Service! Since I started working here in San Francisco I've came here 3 times and yet never left unsatisfied. Though the prices are alil high for whole in the wall but you get exactly what you pay for. I will be a regular here.
author: Dominic A.

description: This place has a long line, but also a better than market-average burrito. Just a tip - know what you want to order before you get here because the menu is high above the line against the wall, and is not very legible from a distance. Also, get here before noon unless you want to wait for fifteen minutes. These guys are quick at turning burritos over and everyone seems at least satisfied, or satisfied enough to come back regularly. Is it the best burrito in San Francisco? No, but that's a subjective decision for you to make on your own.
author: Luis P.

description: This is one of my favorite Mexican spots in the area. Prices are cheap (I generally walk out spending approximately $10) and the food portions are very large. The best thing on the menu in my opinion is the steak chimichanga folllowed by the carnitas California burrito and carnitas super burrito. Definitely give this hole in the wall restaurant a go.
author: Sierra L.

description: One of the best places to grab a cheap breakfast burrito or a hearty lunch. They are very quick and efficient so you never have to wait long on line to order or receive your food. Everything here is great, and they accept cards!
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Love this place! Just wish they were open during nights and weekends since I live a block away!

Very friendly staff.
author: Barry B.

description:
Decent sized super burrito containing both carne asada and al pastor, let me break down the likes and the dislikes of this spot close to the training classes I have on new montgomery.

found on 78 2nd st in SF fairly easy to find if you are walking, it is a little dim inside even though there is lighting on the inside, choices are listed on the far left when you walk in for lunch if you are ordering breakfast there is a separate line in the middle a little to the right. The sauces on the right that are offered seemed a tad slim, mild green sauce for your chips, salsa was emptied out, and the red sauce was also fairly low, it seemed the spicier dark red sauce was the only thing that had plenty to go around mind you it was 11:45am so the lines have not started yet. 

The ordering process it seems they have organized and down pat, walk in, look up order move to the right to pay, get some sauces if there are any available for your chips, no need looking for spoons they only offer forks and knives

I sampled there super burrito with carne asada (steak diced) and al pastor (seasoned pork), the burrito included, latin reddish hued rice, refried beans if not black beans are offered by request, shredded cheese also offered, salsa, sourcream, gauc, mild or hot sauce offered by request and wrapped in a flour tortilla from what I could taste. Portion wise it was decent size enough to get you full but not enough to put you in a coma, the carne asada was slightly salted the al pastor was better seasoned from what I could taste, the mixture of rice, refried beans, sour cream and gauc made it difficult for you to decipher what you were biting down on, but as far as I could tell it was a decent burrito, the was juicy, the sauces found its way out through small ruptures in the tortilla  where you would bite down some sections had no where of moving so ruptures do occur bleeding out all the sauce, get napkins you will need them, unless you like licking your fingers then don't bother. It was not the best burrito I have every had but it was better then average, portion wise good, taste wise on the meats seems they need a tad more flavoring but when meshed all together in the burrito, everything meshed just right.

There are other options they offer like nacho fries, or fries buried in everything you put on nachos, I passed on some of these options, I did not want to be in a coma headed back to work, it is good to know they are offered though

Wash everything down with a cup of their horcata (made from ground almonds, sesame seeds, rice, barley or tigernuts) honestly it I thought it was just made from ground rice, milk and sugar hahha always refreshing if you don't get the bottom of the tub, here is precupped and ready to be distributed.

If you are in the area, this place is decent, not to get you in a coma but enough to make you snore maybe just a little then 1 hour after consuming, be glad to come back and try more of their meat options

burrito *** decent portion, decent flavor on their super burritos if the meat falls out and was not hit by the gauc, or sourcream it is still tender, not super juicy and lightly salted (carne asada) the al pastor was well seasoned
price $ burrito and horcata just over the $10 mark
service **** quick friendly staff
ambiance *** looks older inside, tight fit, small tables, shared by all patrons can sit up to 6 people per table
author: Clarence A.

description:
After much thought, careful consideration, many hollow promises and many failed attempts, I have finally found a "go to taqueria" in downtown SF. I have worked in Financial District for several years and I have been consistently underwhelmed with every burrito place I have gone. 

Finally I have found my spot. Caramba is a no-nonsense taqueria style Mexican joint. You're not going to find tre-sheik burrito/taco concoctions, but if you want a solid burrito, give them a go. They are very efficient, even with long lines you won't be waiting for more than 5 minutes max. Also, they are open for breakfast and they have the best breakfast burritos I have ever had! There's another taco place across the street and Caramba blows them out of the water. 

Doesn't look like much from the outside, but don't let the innocuous black banner fool you. If you're a burrito/taqueria lover, it's the best in all of Financial District/SOMA IMO.
author: Brett L.

description: Good food, good price. Not a fancy, but you have food that you can say Mexican food, compared to other fancy Mexican restaurants in the city. Try the Chimichanga or "carne asada".
author: Paulo R.

description: Hands down favorite burrito in San Francisco. I know that's a bold claim, but Caramba is a hidden gem. In particular, Caramba has delicious super burritos, house made salsas and  breakfast burritos. Great breakfast/lunch spot in FiDi!
author: Al N.

description: Popped in for lunch and had the chicken super burrito with black beans. I liked it, more flavor and better quality than some of the trucks down in the FiDi. Also sampled the horchata, which was a little chalky but delicious. Total cost was about $11, not Mission prices, but not terrible for the area.
author: Patrick S.

description:
I enjoy coming here, since it's close to the office and I know what to expect.  Their breakfast burritos are a bit small, but filled with flavor and inexpensive.  

At lunchtime, I typically order a burrito, but I've also enjoyed their chimichanga's and flauta's.  Take your pick of the variety of meat selections they offer.  I've tried most if not all and try to mix it up all the time.  Like with other Taqueria's, you can help yourself to the salsa bar as needed.  Service is always good and the staff are friendly.
author: Lon H.

description: This is the spot from breakfast burrito . Cheap and served fresh.. I would get the huevos ranchero plate with corn tortillas, extra bacon and watermelon juice. You be working happy after eating it!!!
author: Reynold M.

description: Decided to go here for lunch w a few co workers- def get there by noon to beat the lunch crowd! The line can extend past the door. I had the chile relleno burrito and thought it was okay- I'm from la had have had amazing chile relleno. It could've used more flavor and spices, and cheese wasn't as melted and gooey as I'd like it. Also thought it was weird that they re-heat the chile relleno before wrapping it in the burrito. Nonetheless, they have a lot of choices on  their menu,it's fairly cheap, and have tons of seating.
author: Joy-Alonica B.

description: I was floating between 3 and 4 stars but their service is really good.  The staff is really friendly and man are they fast.  I was laughing about their speed and thinking how great it would be if places like Chipotle moved this fast.  Food is about a 7/10 but service is 9/10.  Just got to get them to carry lengua and cabesa to get 5 stars.
author: Andrew V.

description:
While eating my chicken burrito, all I could say was "Not Good but Not bad" but after eating a few more bites decided it was more towards bad. The entire burrito (chicken, refried beans, rice guac, salsa and onions)  had no distinct taste except for salt. I'm not even sure how that's possible. Also,the burrito was barely warm which didn't help. 
I don't think trying other things would help since it's all made with the same variations. 
It's not the worst but also have no need to return.
author: Diana L.

description:
Nice people, but the worst breakfast burrito I've had in years. Salty, and otherwise mostly tasteless. The eggs were eggs but tasted like nothing, other than hot salty water. Same for the potatoes and salsa in there. The beans didn't even taste much like beans, just more hot salty water.  With a lot of hot salty watery rice.

I've had lunch here twice too and neither burrito was worth coming back for. They weren't awful, but this is a city of good and very good burritos, and you just don't come back to a place that has been in business for many years yet still serves mediocre food.
author: Eric O.

description: I was belching for hours after eating some Fajitas here. I think they use cheap oil.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Not sure why this place has a 3 star rating but I find it really great - taste wise and price wise.
There food/interior/servers are authentic Mexican and Yay! they have plenty of vegetarian options for me.
You have to try their Veggie Quesadilla even if you are a meat lover! This place is best for to-go though the queue here can be big at lunch time. Saying that, they are quick servers. This place is right in front of my office, is super cheap and has vegetarian delicious options for me so yes, I am a frequent eater here and I haven't been disappointed once.

Tip: You have to try their salsa :)
author: Pratibha S.

description:
Authentic, flavorful, fresh food! 
Hats off to the cook[s]. 
All the staff made our late 'burrito' lunch quiet and unhurried.
author: Corinne d.

description:
I am writing this review on behalf of my brother who has come here every Friday for over 1 year. 

He always looks forward to "burrito Friday" with his co-workers and going to Cramba on lunch time. Each time he's gone, he's gotten the same thing. He's very simple, kind of picky, but  reasonable eater. 

Last Friday 11/13, he ordered the same burrito he orders each week, but this time with extra hot sauce. He made it back to work and around an hour after lunch he started feeling ill. He threw up at work twice and was on the toilet back to back. He made it home and told me he didn't feel good. I advised him to relax, drink some water and eat something small and bland. 

By 8:30 pm that night, he was non-stop throwing up and was rushed to the ER. Upon arrival at the ER, he fainted. He was in the restroom throwing up in the ER and he passed out and had to be carried into the bed by nurses. He was immediately IV'd and his body took up 5 bags of fluid which he had lost throughout the day. He was shivering, body was sore, he felt nausea constantly. He was in the ER for 4 hours. They diagnosed him with Food Poisoning and sent him home with nausea and diarrhea pills. 

He was certain there was something wrong with his burrito, he said it just didn't taste the same like it usually does. He was very concerned and doesn't want anyone else to get sick due to lack of attention from cross-contamination. Something had to have been mixed up and for it to hit him 1 hour after eating, it was definitely cross-contamination here which caused severe food poisoning. 

Be mindful, and happy trails!
author: Alyssa M.

description: Great tasting burrito and good location! This is one of the best burritos I've had in SF. The price is good, too. In addition the staff is friendly.
author: Tyler H.

description:
I was severely hungover walking to work this morning, so I decided on a breakfast burrito to cure my morning. After walking about 1 block from BART, I stumbled into Caramba.

The menu is quite confusing. There's lots of regular breakfast choices, and then it just has a breakfast burrito "extras" section. Even in my cloudy hungover state of mind, I'm fairly sure that there's nothing stating what comes in the burrito to start with. So I proceeded to just order my ideal breakfast burrito and ignored the menu altogether.

Service was fairly slow. I ordered take out thinking it was going to be just some eggs, potatoes, and cheese in a tortilla. From ordering to leaving was a good 10 minutes. I would not recommend coming here if you are in any sort of rush.

$5 minimum on credit cards, which is reasonable. I just added a water bottle to my order to bring it up to min.

The overall quality of the breakfast burrito was great and helped me jump start my day.
author: Kailey O.

description: Very greasy and the place does not emanate a good smell in my opinion. Not good for me, comfortable and big restaurant and quantities are big but you can get better burritos at the food truck. Just the name of the place seems so cool.
author: Carmen V.

description:
If you're in the mood for middling-to-mediocre Mexican and don't mind a line at lunchtime, then Ay! Caramba!... this must be the place for you 'cause I ain't that impressed, gringo. I was wondering why nobody around any of the offices I worked at in the area ever talked about this place. Ever. After all, there aren't that many Mexican places in this part of the FiDi where you can grab and go unless you count the 360 Degrees Burritos in the Galleria. But come on, you can't count that, can you? Granted, I have to give credit to the owners of Caramba for trying to open a Mission-style taqueria on Second, but unfortunately, I just wasn't too impressed with what I had.

I thought I should take advantage of the $5.99 Chicken Salad which was admittedly a good price for the portion. The bed of spinach was a nice choice, but then there was the chicken - charred, dried out and hardly edible. It must have been sitting in the warming tray for quite some time to achieve that kind of rubbery texture. The tomato salsa and chip strips did nothing to hide the petty poultry problem (see photo). But hey, of course, I sat there and ate the chips. The people at the other tables didn't seem to have a problem gorging on their burritos and chimichangas, but then again, they looked like they slept in their tattered Macworld T-shirts.

FOOD - 2 stars...dried-out chicken is just not cool...the Instagram photo makes it look far more appetizing than it was
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...crowded at lunch and tables don't get bussed too quickly
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...they look tired
TOTAL - 2 stars...need to satisfy my Mexican cravings elsewhere
author: Ed U.

description:
Caramba is my top lunch location of all-time. I work nearby and it is one of the few Taquerias around me where I can get a decent burrito. I'm a fan of their Al Pastor and Carnitas recipes. The Al Pastor has a mild spiciness to it whereas the Carnitas is very savory.

During the lunch rush, Caramba is quite capable of powering through long lines with their assembly-line process. Rarely have I had to wait longer than 10 minutes to get my burrito. I also find that their burritos are very reasonably-priced for the city.

I'm looking forward to the time when I can reclaim my Dukedom at Caramba. I am very near squelching the rebellion that lost me my throne.
author: Grant S.

description: Very price reasonable this was more of a quantity vs quality experience. I didn't bite into the burrito and say " omg this is a really good burrito "..it was aiigh. El Faro on 24th & Mission is way better then this place.
author: Kam H.

description:
Over the years, I've reviewed a lot of businesses. Some of them were spectacular. Some of them were horrid. Some of them were middle of the road and it took reviewing them to truly understand how I felt about them. Rare is the business that's so... blah that it fails to make an impression during the experience or once I've consulted my notes to jar my memory. Rare.

Ladies & gents, Caramba is just such a business.

Even after reading my notes (taken during my time there), I was hard-pressed to remember the experience. It was only after looking at pictures and reading the corresponding notes (what? Don't look at me like that. Getting these reviews right is part of my job. I take it seriously) that it started coming back to me. But, even then, I wasn't all that inspired to write about my experience. So, that should say something right then and there.

What Caramba has going for it is location, speed and ease of service. In a city like SF with tremendous dining experiences to be had at any price point, if you are offering 'okay' fare, you'd best be bringing something else to the table. In Caramba's case, it's location makes it very convenient to the legions of hungry, stressed and gotta-go types who work in this part of town (spoiler alert: there are lots of them). Knowing the market, the folks at Caramba make sure to get you in and out in a relatively short amount of time. Lastly, there isn't any Elaine-Benes-at-the-soup-nazi-ish hemming and hawing of the menu. It's easy. It's digestible. It's meant to help you make a fast choice, order and be on your way. That said, it's a system that can get jammed up and when my group of seasoned eaters/orderers came in that's exactly what happened. My notes read, 'amazingly, ordering turned into a hot mess.' The trouble came when the woman behind the counter got a bit flustered with our en masse group. That surprises me because I'd imagine that lunch rushes are the usual around here.

As I typically do, I went rogue. I ordered the super nachos with chicken. They were (verbatim from my notes) 'passable.' The chips started off wet and flimsy (what you expect at the end of the nacho gorging). There was little seasoning to be tasted and the ingredients were all of on their own islands. That said, the nachos were piled high and were good for the money. At Caramba, you'll get an okay experience but that's not a surprise (or, worry) for you. You're here to get some food in your belly with relatively little fuss.
author: Johnny T.

description:
3.5 Stars

I was craving chorizo and eggs and my friend always recommends Caramba, but in my one hungover attempt a couple months ago to actually go, I got lost somehow (even though I've worked downtown for several years) and couldn't find the restaurant. Today when I found it, I was like "oh, I've walked past a ton of times, how the eff did I not know THIS was the place".

Anyway, I ordered an Egg, Chorizo, Potatoe, and Cheese Breakfast Burrito with extra hot sauce and jalepenos. Good heat in the hot sauce, the chorizo was savory and oily, mixed with eggs and small bits of potatoe, it was a delight. The service could be nicer and they could clean the place up a bit, but whatever. 

I was so tempted to rip it out of the tin foil and go to town on it on my walk back to the office, but I delayed that, and it was great. The slasas are pretty good, but they don't like to give up their little plastic cups for take away very easily. And each add on is around $1, so my BB was $5.55. Not too bad, I will most likely be back.
author: Crystal C.

description: I love this place. Great crispy tacos; fabulous burritos. Clean, delicious food. Truly Mexican. Great service. I wish that they had a full bar. My ONLY complaint.
author: Jane L.

description: I liked my salad. Really yummy, and a good deal. Well-salted. Spicy salsa!
author: Andrew K.

description:
An 85/100 health score? That's kind of scary, but I ate here and survived. I think I may have found my go-to breakfast burrito spot. I crave b-fast burritos on the reg and this place is quick, convenient, and worthy. I got the works for $6 (Caramba breakfast burrito w/bacon + potatoes + cheese), but pricing generally starts between the $3.50-$3.75 range and potatoes, cheese, or rice are extras that are about $1 each.

Might come back to try out the lunch/dinner options; But for now, I'm for sure a fan of their breakfast.
author: Jaime L.

description:
Seekers of the Mission Street Mexican food experience are likely to encounter a sour note here, since Caramba serves as a "settling" lunch destination more so than a hot spot for cuisine south of the border. Most of the food I've sampled here have been mediocre, leaving me saying "caramba" far more often than "sabrosa!"

Service hasn't been real hot during my last few visits, sometimes the lines get a little out of hand and it becomes a mini human conveyor belt of order food-pay-load up on condiments deal. There haven't been too many smiles from behind the counter, though I imagine I'd be the same way if I were serving this food.

While I've had pretty decent results with their breakfast burrito, all else has become leftovers / scraps on the plate otherwise. I've had soggy tacos dorados on more than one occasion, a few bland and wet burritos (which are not euphemisms for anything other than messy food), and a super sad string of salads (being healthy never tasted so meh).

The prices aren't too terrible, it can get way spendier in this part of SOMA. I wouldn't be surprised if tourists surveying the scene may be mislead to believe this place is a legit Mission burrito spot, but I implore them to head south and don't look back till the street sections become 16th and beyond. When it comes to straight Mission Mexican, Caramba is among the pobrecitos of the bunch.
author: Jando S.

description:
So finding a California Burrito up north is a very hard thing to find. Walked into Caramba expecting an amazing California Burrito.....lets just say there is a reason only Southern Cali makes them. The Burrito just sucked period. 


But alas weeks later hunger got me again and i wandered into Caramba and got the Taco Salad which I really really enjoyed and would recommend!
author: Nina M.

description:
I got a really delicious meal here today. Sopes with chile verde -- ie pork in spicy green sauce and black beans on top of fried cornflour dough shells. It was topped with guacamole, sour cream, shredded cheese and lettuce. I had a fairly run-of-the-mill burrito here a month or so ago, so I wasn't expecting much flavor. I was wrong; this was very tasty and I enjoyed every bite.

Not sure what made my burrito bland before, but I'm willing to guess I wasn't feeling adventurous with the fillings that day. They have a range of meats to choose from, including chicken mole and the above-mentioned chile verde, two of my favorites. Looking forward to trying their other offerings, like tortas and other lunch plates.
author: Laura H.

description:
BEST CHILE VERDE ANYWHERE!!! Their Chile Verde is like Steph Curry!  MVP caliber!
Full disclosure: I get food from here once a week.  Our office gets food catered from here approx. once a quarter. 

We affectionately call this place "Grandma's" because the food has such a home cooked feel to it, it's like eating at your Grandma's house.  The staff is super nice.  Grandma, herself, is awesome!  Lety is super efficient.  Chuy cooks up the best Chile Verde north of Mexico. 

I've been meaning to write a review for a long time, but just never quite executed.  Tonight, however, is Cinco de Mayo and we were too far from Grandma's, so we settled for Gordo's instead. I ordered Chile Verde....it was awful.  So, Gordo's reminded me that this is another place that doesn't stand up to Grandma's. I've been to several Taquerias in the Mission too and they don't stand up to Grandma's.  

So, NOW I have to share with the world about how AWESOME Grandma's Chile Verde is.  Hands down! No competition whatsoever.  Give Grandma's (Caramba) a try...order the Chile Verde!  (in burrito form or as a plato/plate)

One more note, I often gauge a restaurant by its clientele.  Often times, you will see Hispanic construction workers having lunch at this place.  To me, that speaks volume about how authentic this place is.  If Caramba was in the Mission, everybody would be talking how great this place is.  Don't let the location fool you!  Grandma's is as authentic as they come!
author: Sequoia S.

description:
Ay caramba! Not really happy when I ate here.

My mom, sis, and I went to run some errands and were famished. We came here because we were craving tortas (which the signs said they had). I was so sad when I found out that they ran out of some of the ingredients to make them. The employees said that due to being Friday and after the lunch rush, they tend to run out of ingredients much quickly. So, I just ordered a vegetarian quesadilla.

It was meh. I've had better. Not many veggies and way too greasy!

It would have been nice if they stocked their food supplies well to accommodate for the people that want to get some food after the big meal rushes.
author: Terri L.

description:
I just came here for a breakfast burrito because I was craving Mexican food. I got a chorizo with eggs burrito and I paid $1 to add potatoes. While it tasted fine, the burrito was TINY! A small, thin, barely anything burrito that cost almost $5. This place is a huge rip off. I could barely see the potatoes. They're shreds of potatoes, not chunks or cubes. If I am desperate enough to come here again, I would not pay an extra $1 to add potatoes. 

The service was also quite slow. It was fairly crowded with little space to move and wait around. The salsa containers are also behind the counter so you have to ask for them. The napkins are too thin and we waited a long time for our burritos. 

Bottom line, they're charging way too much for a tiny burrito, and skimping on the ingredients and napkins. If they lowered their prices, this place could be decent.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Picked up a Carne Asada Supper Burrito for a quick lunch, and it was better than I expected. I don't know if it will become a usual lunch spot, but I'm sure I'll be back. 

The place was a little dirty, but there was someone actively cleaning like a lunch rush just ended. 

Not a bud lunch spot for sub $10. Going to try a breakfast burrito next time.
author: Zach D.

description: Just went to this place for the first time and it's super good. I went during hectic lunch hour which was a tiny bit overwhelming but the line didn't take very long. I got a California burrito (delicious fries inside) with Barbacoa and was thrilled with it. Reasonably priced and I couldn't finish the whole thing. I recommend checking it out!
author: Clay P.

description: I came here from a recommendation from a friend who also works nearby. I got breakfast burritos for myself and a coworker. You do have to add rice, beans, cheese or potatoes as extra but the original eggs and meat burrito is only $3.50.  You also have to ask for salsa cups at the register because I guess people have taken water cup size salsa in the past. I took my first bite of the burrito and my stomach seriously swooned! I couldn't have been happier! My coworker did the exact same thing on his first bite as well. The salsa was good but not very spicy. I will definitely be back for more breakfast burritos and to try their lunch!
author: Amanda K.

description:
Love it. The 2 ladies at the front are just so nice and always willing. I've become a regular and order my office staff food from here anytime. 
Reasonable cost and always fresh. Burrito, enchiladas, tacos and nachos are superb!
author: K C.

description: This place was delicious. I came by here because my co-workers told me it's a good spot for some real Mexican food. I dropped by here during lunch and the place was packed! There was a line almost out the door and just about every seat was taken. I was fortunately bringing it back to work, so seating wasn't a problem to me. The line moves fast though. Almost too fast that I got to the front without even having time to check the menu. Once again I had read some Yelp reviews so I ordered a super burrito with chicken and no guac. I got to the register very fast paid for my food and added a Mexican Coke. The lady was nice, but was moving the kind fast, so I wouldn't say it was very memorable. The burrito was delicious!!!!! I really loved the freshness of it all and enjoyed the Coke to top it off. It's still a bit pricey to me, but for the financial district t it's about what t expect (paid about $10 bucks). Overall, I will definitely come by here to eat some more things off the menu!
author: James R.

description:
I come here at least once or twice a week, and always get the regular burrito or super burrito with spicy salsa. Their burritos, in my opinion, taste better than what the nearby Chipotle has to offer. The lines move quickly and I've never had to wait for more than a few minutes to get my food, even at lunch time on a weekday. At $6.75, regular burritos are one of the cheaper lunch options in the area. The super burrito costs $1 extra and comes with cheese, sour cream, and guac.

However, I felt the menu was unintuitive and hard to read in general. For burritos specifically, nowhere on the menu does it say I can choose between black, pinto, or refried beans. Also, the menu doesn't list the different types of meat they offer - I've tried the chicken and steak, but there are at least two more meats that I haven't been able to identify yet.
author: Benson Q.

description:
I can only speak for the eponymous breakfast burrito. And to it I say:

Get it.
Get it spicy.
Get it with chorizo.
Get it with potatoes.
Get it on the day that your company doesn't spring for breakfast burritos for the whole company, so you don't walk into your office having paid for something you were about to get for free.

¡Ay caramba! (I bet I'm the first person to say that here.)
author: Peter D.

description: thank fucking god for this place, or else this stupid neighborhood full of stupid ppl would only have one proper food establishment. the nicest people work here and are ready to serve the most delicious, lettuce-less burritos in SF. I'm serious. the most delicious burritos in all of SF are right here on 2nd st. plus they give you an entire bag of chips that is literally 200% more chips than any other taqueria... and their salsa verde is the ultimate salsa verde. I lose my shit for it. I even buy it in pints and take it home sometimes. their napkins are the perfect thickness, and not surprisingly, if you ask them for more napkins or more salsa cups in a non-asshole, non imposing way, they will be happy to give you some. THANK U KANYE FOR CARAMBA.
author: Yves D.

description:
I LOVE this place. It's the only good REAL Mexican food in the FiDi. I come here once a week or so. My favorite it the chili relleno burrito and the taco salad (I'm 98% sure the "bowl" is baked, not fried.). 

Though honestly, everything is good. The taquitos are killer and FILLING. I got a crispy chicken taco with beans and rice for $7.50 or so. The chili verde is some of the most tender pork I've ever had.

LOVE this place. If you want something classy with white table cloths, head somewhere else. 
This is quick and real Mexican, with meats cooked looooonng slow.
author: Lara E.

description:
I came here because I didn't really have time to stand  in the long Chipotle line--it's not that good.

This place is a nice, unassuming spot. I just wanted a steak quesadilla. Simple lunch. And clearly the quesadilla was just that. It was pretty bland, weak portion size, but it was cheap (~6.14.) Not sure I would ever order that again if I did come back though. 

It's really a two stars place but I think they honestly mean well & the food is cheap. So---three stars.
author: Juan T. K.

description:
For $5 you get a mediocre Subway sandwich down the street. Don't get me wrong, I have the $5 sub all the time. For $7.65 you get a plate of carne asada, beans, rice and guacamole. This is their lunch special. 

See: http://media3.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/GWZ30eJssgAzHLniDGHr6g/l

The carne asad itself is average but the whole plate is a great deal and in combination is a pretty damn good meal if you're hungry and want an actual meal.
author: Carlos A.

description: This place is among the better in soma area. Typical sf taqueria. The line gets long so best time to show up is 11:45.
author: Will D.

description: I ordered the super burrito with black beans and beef. The one thing that stood out was the richness of the sour cream. The service was really fast.
author: James S.

description:
I've only ever visited in the morning and only ever ordered the breakfast burrito. My advice to you would be to limit your adventures here to the Caramba (that's the official name for their breakfast burrito: two scrambled eggs, your choice of bacon, ham or chorizo, bell pepper and onion). 

I like my Caramba best with chorizo and the addition of potatoes. Be prepared to repeat your order multiple times as service is a little spacey. I've become accustomed to this and figure it's worth it for a morning meal that's super satisfying and of pretty great value.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Went here to get breakfast for a vegetarian friend. Burritos came out fairly quickly and looked decent - until my friend took a bite of hers and discovered a bunch of ham. I went back and explained what happened (ham in a veggie burrito). The cashier looked in the bag, saw the ham, and said I must have ordered a ham burrito. I explained that I hadn't, and that the foil had "veggie" marked on the side. Then the cook came over, dumped the bag out on the counter, and started yelling that it was veggie, despite the pieces of ham clearly visable. They then agree to make a new burrito, and proceed to give me the smallest burrito I've ever seen (about the size of an Altoid tin) and told me to get out.
Rude, terrible customer service like this ensures that I will never be coming back. I'd rather walk to 1st Street and go to El Faro - they have better food anyway.
author: Rich Y.

description:
May be the best breakfast burrito I've ever had.
Go with: Chorizo + Egg, plus Potato and Cheese, Spicy.
author: Nic N.

description: Defintily one of my favorite burrito places in Downtown for lunch. The California Burrito is my favorite, because they add fries *in addition* to the rice! Gotta love my carbs!
author: Bryan M.

description: Found this "little gem" (hole in wall) two weeks ago...been here for lunch every day since.  Their Chile Relleno Burrito is my favorite.  Lines are long at lunch but moves quickly.  Ordering may seem a bit chaotic, people screaming out their orders.  By the second day I was ordering like a boss. Only downside is my ever-expanding waistline.
author: Francisco C.

description:
$3.95 breakfast burritos that are about the size of your open hand. Just to be clear - that's not a complaint. A perfectly-sized breakfast for a very reasonable price. 

My favorite is the caramba burrito - with chorizo and spicy. You can also add potatoes, if you're into that. But i like mine as it comes - eggs, onions, peppers, meat. Nomnomnomnom! It comes out piping hot because you can actually watch the ladies in the back crack eggs for your burrito. Definitely made with love!

A few tips you should know....
~ Make sure to ask for cups for salsa while you order.
~ They have a $5 minimum for credit/debit cards, so order accordingly or bring some cash
~ Breakfast ends at 10:30, and it gets busy at 10am.

Enjoy!
author: Mar A.

description:
I may go back, but I was not impressed. The carne asada platter is not great. The meat was just okay and not even cut up. So the to-go box and the plastic fork and knife were not ideal for cutting the beer. The rice was dry and too orange (seemed like coloring?) and the beans were watery and un-flavorful. They skimped on the guacamole and the lettuce was watery and shredded. In all I'd say the meal was just okay and tolerable, but nothing tasty. 

Service: Though they line you up and take orders quickly in an assembly line, they somehow forgot to make my order when I got to the cash register. I had to wait on the side while I then gave instructions again on what I wanted. 

Go to Chipotle down the street.
author: Maryam M.

description:
OK Mexican in the FiDi.

It is difficult to find authentic taqueria food in the FiDi, so Caramba is a Mecca for burrito and taco lovers. The portions are huge, the prices reasonable.  

The super burrito was really super-sized.  Do not order it, if you are on a diet.  (Note: This is a down-scale place, so no whole wheat, spinach, or tomato tortillas; it's flour, plain and simple.). If you like spicy, order the spicy chicken with spicy salsa; it'll blow your socks off.  The nacho fries are to-die-for: nachos and fries all in one. Duh!  Someone should have thought of this sooner.  With enough cheese to shame Wisconsin, the quesadillas are awesome.  Gooey, sticky, and stringy. Yum.

This is not a frou-frou Mexican place, must copious portions of generally tasty Mexican food.  There are better tacos and burritos in The City, but considering the (lack of) selection/competition in the FiDi, Caramba rocks.
author: CJ G.

description: I have been religiously looking for a place to top this place only to find no other Mexican restaurant around this neighborhood comes close to their quality of food that Caramba offers.  My favorite is their chile relleno, extremely tasty and never dried out like the other place around the corner.  Price is very reasonable. And service if fairly quick.
author: Jeff H.

description: You know when it's not a good place when you get pissed off by their customer service. I order a caramba with extra egg but I don't think they add extra egg. I order on a plate and they make it a burrito. Their handling of food is not something you want to watch, they don't use gloves. They're arrogant also with no customer service at all.
author: Noel O.

description:
I read the reviews prior to my visit. I was really excited to try the chorizo breakfast burrito. I asked for it to be spicy, added potatoes and added cheese.

I also asked for the salsa containers to get extra hot sauce. The small burrito was yummy, just as long as each bite was drenched in hot salsa.

The pictures of dishes on the wall look good, and the prices look great. 
I think I would like to try the huevos rancheros next time, as well as the tortas. It's not too far for work, so I'm going to try it again soon. The staff was really nice.
author: Rosie M.

description: Sadly decent at best. I work very close by and ran over here to get lunch (after the noon rush....at 3. Yay meetings!) and ordered the Super Nacho Fries. Sadly, the name does not correlate to what I have gotten. I like cheese and assumed that "super nacho" means a lot of cheese. There was almost none. There were some cheese....the spots on the box walls had the nuked cheese stuck on it. And that's about it. I'm happy with the servings of meet though (only 3 meats: chicken, beef, and pork). A good portion of avacado and sour cream. Fries are few but the meat made it up. I should've gotten the burrito instead. Also, they do NOT take AMEX but Visa is good. For $10+...I'd say not worth it. Maybe I'm used to South Bay's portioning and prices. Oh well, lesson learned. Also, if you have a wood desk like I do, do not let the box sit on top of it. Maybe because they microwaved it to hell but the box left a stain on my desk.
author: A o S.

description: I is an authentic Mexican food. I ate here almost every week and found the taste very consistent, texture of spices is right. I like their super burrito and casadilla.
author: Laxman A.

description:
Caramba is delicious. Its a no frills Mexican food breakfast or lunch spot with amazing burritos.

What do people expect? its a lunch spot that makes a burrito in less than 60 seconds for $6 an it tastes good. Do you want the nachos to dance for you before you eat them!? If you like mexican this place is on point for a quick bite.
author: Petey F.

description: The only reason this isn't 5 is because the service... Breakfast burritos will rock your world!
author: Bob P.

description:
There's only one reason to go to Caramba: can you say "breakfast burrito?"  I tried a regular burrito here once, and it wasn't particularly good.  But the breakfast burritos are something else entirely.  Get the "Caramba" with bacon, which nets you egg, bacon, bell peppers, onion, and hot sauce in a perfectly sized morning gut bomb.  It's somehow otherworldly. and only costs a couple of bucks.

Delicious, though probably not all that nutritious.
author: Laurence W.

description:
Nothing starts my day off better than a breakfast burrito. And when I can add potatoes into the breakfast burrito I'm a happy girl. I don't necessarily think potatoes belong in all burritos, but they do go well with my breakfast so I like them in there.

The ladies that are up front in this joint are fast and friendly. They cook your eggs on a little hot plate right behind the register. You can get your burrito made to your liking whether you want eggs or not, meats, hot or mild salsa, cheese, etc. I even saw Gabi K order a whole wheat tortilla and avocado for hers I think.

Long review short - not a fancy burrito place and it's good for morning fuel.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Stars for the service. I ordered huevos rancheros and my eggs were under cooked the lady looked horrified and wanted to recook the eggs for me, but I prefer them like that so no problem. 

Orders were unorganized and my rice was very burned and crunchy! A big no no . I've had better Mexican food in SF.
author: Meghan M.

description:
The huevos rancheros breakfast burrito is amazing and I think it's less than $6.  The verde salsa is great here too.  The service is pretty good too.

YUM!
author: Chris L.

description: I might be in love: the best breakfast burrito (carumba burrito) I've ever had for less than $5... Nuff said
author: Lauren G.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review about Caramba earlier. This is THE best Mexican restaurant in the FiDi that I have found. The name is cornball and I initially had no faith this place would be good but I've fallen in love. Skip the chain restaurants and walk another block over to some better Mexican food.

The food here is fresh, authentic and beyond satisfactory every time! They make the food right in front of you so if you are picky or have food allergies make sure to watch them and be very clear. This is an authentic spot so many of the workers have thick accents and a coworker of mine with food allergies had a bad experience due to a language barrier. 

Many of my Yelp peeps know how much I love their chile verde burrito (CVB). It is like no other from anywhere I have ever had. And for the record the sauce is actually green (I know that sounds like a no brainer but trust me, it's not always green at other places). My coworker loves and orders the chicken mole burrito. Personally, I have not tried it but he swears it's bomb. 

They serve breakfast and lunch but I'm not sure about dinner. They now use Order Ahead to take individual on-line orders (ALWAYS a fan of that service). I just recently tried their breakfast burritos and they are to DIE for! However, they are pretty small and it will leave you craving more (sad face). They also have a healthy variety in their salsa bar: a couple hot, a couple mild and a green salsa. I believe they have chopped, pickled carrots and jalapenos too. 

The cons about this place besides a potential language barrier is sometimes they don't honor their check-in deals such as Yelp app (ahem) or other programs unless you have a physical paper print out (how you print out a mobile check-in offer is beyond me). Perhaps they lack internal communication of how to accept such deals but don't count on that free agua fresca or soda with check-in.

Besides the cons, the food speaks for itself. Also, you might want to add a nice cold brew with your lunch. They have a pretty good selection of Mexican beer such as Modelo, Pacifico, and Dos Equis.
author: Chanelle N.

description:
Just left & had to throw my burrito away! The steak was disgusting and when I asked for no rice the lady scrapped it off. 

I would not recommend this place. Especially with so many amazing Mexican restaurants in SF.
author: Kelly T.

description:
Damn,

There is just no excuse for a bland burritto with crunchy, tasteless meat. I mean if I had a burritto like this in Iowa or something, I would say "no shock there," but no excuse for this in SF.  I would take Chipotle over this any day!  Very disappointing rubbish
author: Jim B.

description:
I have this theory that virtually any hangover can be cured by a Caramba Breakfast Burrito. Their Chorizo + Egg (I like to add cheese to this) is by far my favorite. It's not just the fact that these little baby breakfast burritos (burrititos if you will) are filling, they are also pretty yum. 

I appreciate that I can order ahead online and haven't ever had a conflict thus far placing larger orders for my office, particularly the day after a rowdy outing ;-).
author: Chris W.

description:
I wholeheartedly agree with another yelp reviewers experience (Jennifer). Everything that I needed to say is said there about my sad breakfast burrito. 

Would not come back for a poor baby breakfast burrito. Better off not having one if that's what your thinking.
author: Anton H.

description: Bland and microwaved depending on what you get. That AND no gloves? Pass.
author: Renee F.

description: If you get there before the lines start at 12;30, this is a quick, healthy lunch spot with some solid offerings.  I recommend the Shrimp Bandarillas with the spicy sauce.  Simple fresh veggies and shrimp skewered and grilled for around $8.00 -- YUM
author: Christine C.

description: Walked over and was in and out in 5 minutes. I got a super shredded chicken burrito w/ spicy sauce + fresh cliantro. It was delicious. I will be back to try more things off their menu.
author: Jennifer Z.

description: This place makes some pretty baller burritos. Of legit mexican places that I've been to in DT SF this ranks in the top tier. Their meats have got a good amount of flavours in em' which really adds to the burrito experience. And the meats aint dry, nice n' juicy. Burritos are also damn cheap, like 8 bucks. That's a win. If you are in the mood for a burrito thats got that could potentially make ya go 'dAAAmmnn daaaaMMNN dAAAAAMN' give this place a shot.
author: David C.

description: 5/5 for Chicken Super Burritos to go. A little more expensive than Chipotle but worth it.
author: Jared R.

description: Went here for lunch today and it was good. It hit the spot and they were fast. Hard to find a good taqueria down here in SoMa, so this will have to do; at least it beats chipotle's weak attempt at Mexican food. Gotta love the way they work as a traditional burrito line, and of course they offer a great variety of other dishes such as tacos, plates, enchiladas, wet burritos etc.. I'd go back for sure.
author: Bradley C.

description: Love the veggie breakfast burrito!!!  open early. Friendly. Flat out delicious. And good spicy salsa! A must have for those early mornings at Dreamforce!!!
author: Elliott Y.

description: We came here for a quick lunch while in SF for work. It reminded me of a local version of Chipotle with the layout and type of food. This is no frills Mexican food and was decent. It provided me with a hearty meal that got me through the rest of the day. I ordered the tacos with half pico and half spicy sauce. The spicy sauce is definitely spicy so approach with caution. At first we thought it was cash only, but realized they also accept cards. If you are in the area and looking for a quick Mexican food lunch, this is a good option.
author: Lindsey D.

description:
Went in for a breakfast burrito. The Caramba Chorizo. Waited a bit for mine, but I guess that was actually a good sign for me. It means that it was made to order; not made in batch first thing in the morning. It was good, but not great. But hey, for a little more than $3, its a deal.

Would go back since its close to work, but its not my go to burrito shop.
author: Eric C.

description:
This place is convenient, fast, and filling.  It's also sort of bland (referring to the super burrito with al pastor, black beans, rice, cheese, guac, sour cream, and salsa on a whole wheat tortilla, $7.34).  Then again, coming from San Diego, I have extremely high standards for Mexican food. 

Will probably come again for the California burrito (burrito with fries), but if the fries are crispy, then they'll probably miss me.
author: Ronald T.

description:
Breakfast Burrito review only!  

So the breakfast burritos here at a bit on the tiny side but they are cheap and customizable which is a big plus!  You can get it however you like, and if you ask for it spicy, it's got some good kick!

I'd suggest maybe ordering more than one at a time since they aren't humongo.  But they taste good and they are really nice here.
author: Gene X.

description: Lousy organization and marginal food. Prices are ok, but be prepared to feel ill overall.
author: Chris T.

description: A bomb veggie taco. First one I had in SF, I'm from LA and we're spoiled when it comes to bomb Mexican food. I've been disappointed in the Mexican fare in the Bay Area but this was a pleasant surprise!
author: Vahagn M.

description:
I was hoping for a 4  but it was a 3 star experience.  

1.  It was busy but the line went very quickly.

2.  I like the system of one person taking and preparing your order.  It gives a very personal feel.

3.  Everyone was friendly.

4.  If you want to eat in, a number of the tables are pretty cramped because the line-up to order.

5.  The canned drinks from their cooler were Cold with a Capital C.  I like really cold beverages with Mexican food.

6.  Carne Asada Plate (Meat, Choice of beans, Choice of tortilla, Lettuce, Rice, Guacamole) - This was a pretty good plate.  The meat was tender but could of used a little something.    The lettuce, refried beans,rice, etc.. were basic and what you would expect.  It was filling.  I enjoyed it but nothing really leaped out to say "wow, that was a great carne asada plate".

http://tinyurl.com/4esrjp7

7.  They do have a sauce bar with a number of sauces.  I mixed some together and enjoyed it with my carne asada.

8.  Overall, this was a good lunch experience.  The service was fast.  The price was decent (just over $11 including 2 canned soft drinks and one entree plate).  I enjoyed it but it didn't really stand out.
author: Mark D.

description:
Their breakfast burrito is perfect.

Egg, bacon, salsa, under $3.  Not huge, but delicious, and the perfect size for a quick grab-n-go breakfast.

I absolutely love it.

Lunch looked of the boring "steam tray" variety, so that's why no 5 stars.
author: Rocco B.

description: Stopped by this place for lunch. The line was a bit long, but the food is pretty cheap, and portion sizes are good. With that said, it won't be a daily spot, but I'll come back for sure.
author: Greg M.

description: Delicious breakfast burrito.  Chirizo, egg, and potatoes with extra hot sauce.  I will definitely return!
author: Cody P.

description: Came here for a quick bite before a round of meetings (which turned out to have catered bfast burritos. Kara is a b$tch) and grabbed a Popeye special (mushrooms, eggs, spinach, pico, hot sauce). The cost, with cheese added, was under 4$. Win. The wait wasn't long at all and the size was perfect (that's what she said). If it was any bigger I would've needed a nap (she said this, too). Tried some of my buddies chorizo bfast burrito and it was solid as well. I can't speak for the whole menu, but for a quick AM snack. Stop on in!
author: Drew A.

description:
Yea I'm a certified gringo but I know wassup with mexican grubbs.  This is really the only spot in FiDi to get authentic, but they don't blow it.

The chick with the funky hair asks you like 3 times what you want but - 

Enchiladas and a taco - DO IT.
author: Farrell W.

description: Best breakfast burritos in the area. I know there's a few places within a couple blocks that serve breakfast burritos but these are the most flavorful and "authentic".They make the eggs fresh with each order. Order the Caramba with bacon and potatoes, SPICY!
author: Alexa H.

description:
If you work around the area, you probably work at some tech company. 

Which means you're probably in your early-mid 20s and you're out drinking on weekdays. 

Here's where you get that breakfast burrito to cure your hangover. 

Bring it back and eat it at your desk with your sunglasses on like a champ. 

Don't forget the red/green salsas.
author: Louie M.

description:
Popeye con bacon!

Our office lights up with joy when I bring these bad boys in on a Friday morning..   They're the perfect size and come with Bacon, egg, spinach, and mushrooms.
author: Mike M.

description: My favorite place to get a burrito within walking distance of my job. The food is always fresh and tasty and lines move fairly well. Minus 1 star because I can finish the supper burrito in one sitting.
author: Nikhil V.

description: San Francisco is a city known for its great burritos. As a result of living here for quite some time, I've developed this craving for cheap, quick, extremely filling Mexican food. Unfortunately, places that fit this description are pretty far away from where I work (I have taken the Bart to Mission during lunch time a few times, but I soon realized that this solution would not be scalable) and I really do need a quick fix where I could walk to, order a veggie burrito, see the burrito being prepared right in front of my eyes and then paying half of what I usually end up paying at any place in the SoMa/FiDi area. Caramba's burritos aren't the best I've had, but they are good enough to answer my weekday lunchtime mexican food cravings. Google Translate says that the word "Caramba" means "an expression of surprise or dismay" Luckily for me, the place neither surprises me nor dismays me. The food's consistent. It's warm. It's a lot.
author: Srivatsan S.

description: I came with colleagues and absolutely fell in love.  I could just about eat their burritos everyday for the rest of my life!  The food is fresh, the service efficient, I will definitely be back and often!
author: Angela A.

description: I used to come here all the time for a fresh breakfast burrito, but one time I ate here with my boy JR and it destroyed both of our stomachs. By destroy I mean ravaged. Let's just say the loo was my best friend for the next couple of days. It could've just been that one time, but not sure if I want to risk it. Should I? The breakfast burritos do taste pretty #trill
author: Amar S.

description:
I got two tacos here. One Al Pastor and one Carne Asada, I left feeling aSADa. 

Word play aside, the meat was lacking in flavor and wasn't very tender. That doesn't make a good taco, since there aren't many other ingredients.

The salsa was good. I think I'd go for a quesadilla or something else next time, though my coworker didn't finish her quesadilla either so it doesn't seem that appealing.

No bueno.
author: Viet N.

description: There are not a lot of Mexican places in downtown, but Caramba is a solid choice. The carnitas burrito is delicious. No compromises here. Great lunch option.
author: Karla R.

description: I've only been here for breakfast burritos, but they're amazing! Seriously the best breakfast burrito I've had in a long time. I get the bacon, egg, cheese, and potato burrito with spicy sauce and it's fantastic. Crispy, flavorful, etc. etc.
author: Mike W.

description:
Here's how the San Francisco taqueria review process works: 

1. White kids from Arcata move here to go to art school and sell weed having grown up on a steady diet of Chevy's and Hey Juan's.

2. They get some shitty dive apartment in the Mission where they can play their god-awful screamo music as loud as they want and their stoner roommate takes them to some random restaurant within walking distance.

3. The monster bong rips that made them hilarious and creative observational humorists also make them think that the food they encounter is the best thing on earth (and that Chrome bags are things they need to ask their parents to purchase for them).

4. They get jobs at GitHub or AirBnB and go post negative reviews of every other Mexican restaurant in town, claiming that they're not "authentic."

There's nothing particularly amazing about Caramba, but it's about as good as most of the other places all these one-star-givers rant and rave about, and it's as cheap as it gets in this neighborhood. Yeah, I've gotten a couple clumps of dried-out rice, and the horchata is grainy as hell, but the same can be said of 90% of the "authentic" places. I like it and I'm going back.
author: Nicholas J.

description: Paltry compared to the mexican offerings in the Mission, but this isn't bad for downtown. I had the caramba quesadilla (spinach, mushroom, and cheese), which was good, but greasy. Quick and easy.
author: Marcel M.

description: Best stinking place for breakfast! Everywhere else nearby on this side of market st charges $8-12 and microwaves your eggs! This place? $3.10 for a fantastic breakfast burrito made right then and there. They have other things, but I won't get tired of the breakfast burritos for a while.
author: Eric I.

description:
The burrito is always on point at Caramba's. 

I frequent here since I work right down the street and the food has always been consistent. The prices are reasonable and the location is awesome. The place does get a little too crowded during lunch time with the line going out the door most times. The staff is really rushed all the time and their salsas are OK. If you are tired of eating Chipotle burritos then I'd suggest coming here to try something different. Although I haven't tired it, I keep hearing that their tortas are great. One of the perks about Caramba's is that the menu is stacked with Mexican dishes and they even have Carne Asada Fries! 

All in all this is a great place to get away from the usual sandwich/gyro spots in the SOMA.
author: Javier G.

description:
More like a 3.7.

I went with a co-worker, I was ravenously craving Mexican, but not Chipolte Mexican... we got the recommendation and walked the short blocks to the restaurant. Walking up there wasn't much differentiating from other lunch spots, but there was a long line, almost out the door, which to me was a good sign.

I ordered the Super Burrito - for me this seemed more like a regular burrito, although that could be because I was so hungry. I ordered it with grilled chicken, rice, black beans, mild salsa, sour cream and guac. I added spicy salsa after, it needed more of a kick, but having never gone there I wasn't sure how spicy their sauces were. Definitely was fresh, and the flavors stood out. Next time I would order the carne asada. 

Very reasonable, fast, convenient. It hit the spot.
author: Jess K.

description: If you are looking for a delicious, inexpensive breakfast burrito in the Financial District, this is the place to go! I'm not exaggerating when I say I I come here 3-4 times a week to pick one up to start my morning. The staff is always pleasant, the salsas are flavorful, and everything else is on point. Ask for whole wheat tortillas! SO GOOD!
author: Taylor H.

description:
Caramba is a small Mexican restaurant with a few tables and seats inside. There's a counter to order and it goes straight to the cash register after.

== Food ==

Nachos was quite alright. Chips felt kind of old. The steak was pretty decent and the rest of the veggie stuff was quite fresh. Overall, an alright nacho.

== Service ==

Quick and fast to go service.

== Overall == 

Pretty alright place for authentic Mexican food.
author: Steven B.

description:
Like many other reviewers, I went specifically for the chorizo breakfast burrito after a co-worker suggested it. And I was not disappointed! Note, I called ahead, but you can also order online. It was ready in 10 minutes.

The order:
Chorizo and Egg burrito
*add cheese
*add potatoes
*make it spicy


I really enjoyed it! It wasn't soggy, like other ones I've had (like the one across the street with the big red awning... you know who you are) who use really watery salsas that make it soggy and spill out the bottom. That totally ruins a burrito for me. Unlike other Chorizo burritos I've had, their meat is much more crumbly so you get some in every bite (which they don't skimp on anyway). And the size was perfect! I don't need to be eating a Chipotle sized burrito at 9am in the morning. I will definitely be back!
author: Anne-Marie H.

description: Decent spot which I've passed by more than a hundred times but never ate at.  I had the steak super burrito and it wasn't the most amazing thing I've ever had but it served it's purpose and was a good lunch.
author: Blake B.

description:
San Francisco seems to be the city of breakfast burritos!  I come in for meetings several times a year, and every time I'm here, I see my colleagues chowing down each morning on breakfast burritos.
