I usually start my day out with oatmeal, fruit, coffee, or yogurt and granola... but I mixed it up today.  I had to know what the burrito obsession was all about, so I gave in today and visited Caramba on my way into the office.

I was pleased to see that there were options.  Not only could I choose from eggs, cheese, potatoes, beans, rice, chorizo, etc... but Caramba offers whole wheat tortillas!  I filled one of these savory steamed wraps with eggs, hot salsa, and guacamole... it came neatly wrapped in foil and upon unwrapping it once I was settled in at the office, the scent escaped and got me oh so excited!

This was one burrito worth waiting for.  It was love at first bite - I think I'm now hooked!  While the burrito itself was not humongous, it was just the right size.  (Yes, there is such a thing as one that is too big!)  But this one filled me up and left me wanting more.  I now understand the SF obsession with breakfast burritos - I'll be back to Caramba during future visits, and I may even seek out a breakfast burrito place closer to home when the craving strikes.

By the way, this was my review #666: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g7-iG4IyF2w
author: Gabi M.

description:
I'll point out that my review is ONLY for the breakfast burrito. I've had lunch here a couple of times because I live in the neighborhood, an it was unacceptable. Their regular menu is a far cry from the taquerias in the MIssion.

But their breakfasts burrito is probably my favorite in SF. It's a little on the small side, but it's dense with eggs, meat, onions, and bell peppers. I also like to add potatoes to mine. All in all, it's a great value at just under $5.

PROS
- Very hearty and filling breakfast burrito
- Excellent spice factor, especially with chipotle salsa

CONS
- Really only good for breakfast

TIPS
- Cash only, but they do have an ATM
- Get the Caramba and add potatoes
author: Drew P.

description:
I love this place, burritos are great (dispite the rare occasional mis-wrap or the tear from the lady banging the rice spoon on the tortilla to get the rice off the spoon but can you be mad at her for giving you all the food you can get?), line is usually long until about 2pm but moves every fast!

It's only open for a couple of hours on weekdays but it's quick, convenient, reasonably priced, really good AND the very attractive, friendly woman at the register keeps me coming back daily (literally).

I wish they were open later and on weekends.
author: Kevin V.

description:
I was heading to a taco truck when I passed Caramba and realized I was too hungry to make it to my intended destination. And they were hawking their carne asada special--what's not to love? But what a mistake-I should have held out for the truck! This was by far the blandest asada I've ever had-it wasn't seasoned AT ALL. No heat, no spice, no sauciness at all, just a few flat strips of steak. The portion was big, but thanks to the taste I was in no way interested in finishing.

I hear the burritos are good, but I have other favorites for those and if they can't pull off a basic like carne asada I don't trust their other items as far as I can throw them.

The lesson here? When in doubt, chose the truck.
author: Lesly S.

description: Perfect size breakfast burritos made to order.
author: Travis S.

description:
Not only do I totally LOVE this place, but they saved my butt today. At 11:07 my boss rings my desk and wants lunch for 9ppl at noon. In SF Financial Dist, this is the busiest time for large orders. Where to go, what to do. Then I remember 1/2 a block away, Caramba has great food, made to order and they are pretty fast. I walk in their doors at 11:25, at 11:45 I'm walking out with a boat load of food and one if their employees helping me carry it back. They are AWESOME and EFFICIENT!
They also have the most authentic tasting Mexican food in the area. (street food style) I also tasted some things I would not have orederd for myself and now have some new favorites:
Enchiladas the sauce ROCKS!!
Chicken Salad, good lettuce, grilled chicken- yum

I got here at least once a week, they have are starting to recognize me. THANK you Caramba crew for getting me out of a tight situation!!
author: Monica H.

description:
"Captain! We have a problem with the containment field and I fear we may have an imminent warp core breach!"

If we substitute the phrase "containment field" with tortilla and "Warp core" with burrito filling, This quote, lovingly stolen from Star Trek: The Original Series (imagine James Doohan saying it), would sum up my entire burrito experience at Caramba. 

Evidence of a breach appeared as I unwrapped the foil, seeing sauce leaks at every corner. While the meat (Chicken Mole) was tender and rather tasty, the guacamole distribution dead on and the warmth of the burrito consistent throughout, there was little cheese in evidence and the spiciness of the burrito (I prefer my burrito's to be palate-scorchingly spicy) was...underwhelming. In fact, spice was definitely absent, as was any flavor characteristic of a Mole sauce.

The hot sauces offered were a nice touch (the chipoltle salsa helped to kick the meal's spiciness up) and I enjoyed the pickled vegetable mixture, they were not enough to save this meal from the depths of mediocrity that it was consigned to because of the poorly constructed burrito.

However, the horchata was outstanding (top 5 in my life without a doubt) and being able to sit outside on a warm San Francisco afternoon and gnaw on a slab was a rare delight.

If they work on the construction of their burritos and their spice, I'd be more then willing to add a third (and possibly fourth) star.
author: Casey U.

description: Good simple breakfast burritos. I had mine with eggs & chorizo and washed it down with Jarritos tamarind flavored drink. Great price about $6.
author: Rajeev R.

description:
No bull indeed.

I was going to give four stars even before discovering the awesome bull logo on their website. Always. Fresh. No Bull. That's a bold promise to live up too.

And they did. Shrimp burrito is one of the best downtown. Packed with both shrimp and grilled peppers. Lettuce at no charge instead of rice. Plenty of black beans. Wheat tortilla. Less than seven bucks.

I made a mess eating while walking back the office. The plan was just one bite. Could stop until it was all gone.

That's no bull.
author: Jason B.

description: I can't believe this place is getting 3.5 stars.  The only good thing about it is that it seems fairly clean.  The food is very bland.  I ordered a chile relleno plate, and the guy grabbed a pre-fried chile from a stack and tossed it into the microwave.  Later I overheard the people next to me saying their burrito was cold inside.  Nah--this place is not for me.
author: Kandi K.

description:
Caramba is a great authentic mexican spot in SOMA/Financial district that can satisfy any lunch customer's hunger.

The folks at Caramba churn out delicious authentic mexican food at a reasonable / affordable price. It's a great spot for pick up, but I like to take a seat and enjoy the food in house.

My go to is 2 soft tacos. I really like the carnitas - the meat is boldly spiced and cooked to be perfectly tender. The Chicken, can be overcooked/dried out at times, but the authentic hot salsa and fresh pico/cilantro are a home run in my book.
author: Justin O.

description:
Fast service, good food , and convenient location from my office.

Meal comes with chips and there is a salsa bar. If you eat in, there is different hot sauces you can choose from sitting at the table already.  I have had other Mexican food around the area and I always enjoyed this place the most.
author: Panda G.

description: I have come here alot! Their breakfast burritos are the BOMB! I have had a chorizo egg potatoes burrito! It was delicious! I will continue to come here for a breakfast fix!
author: Kyle W.

description:
Was wandering around for lunch near NextspaceSF; stumbled upon Caramba and walked right in.

The menu/ordering process is a bit confusing and hectic, but the line-workers are straightforward and brisk. The line might look intimidating, but it moves fast with the efficient workers.

I ordered a torta with al pastor: I've had bigger (and better) tortas in the past, but this one hit the spot for my lunchtime hunger. Flaky fresh pork sliced up between a warmed roll...mmmm. Also, love that they provide lettuce greens (NOT the generic lettuce) and avocado. 

Be sure to pay attention when they call out your order for pick-up; don't get it mixed up with someone else's! Luckily I was the only one who had ordered a torta, so I didn't have that issue. Others ordered burritos, though, so they had to be more vigilant.

Cash only for $5 and under; they accept cards above that amount. Next time, I'll have to try out their horchata; today I decided to go for a Diet Coke.
author: Helene K.

description: Good breakfast burrito, but nothing too special.
author: Jonah K.

description: Caramba wins over Chipotle.  Both are very near my office but Caramba has a Mexican warmth that no one can match.  The Mexican ladies who prepare the orders are all very friendly, vivacious and humor me as I try to converse in Espanol with them. This food itself is good.  Do not expect elegant plating or fancy sides.  It is what it is: comfort burritos that hit the spot at a reasonable price.
author: Ronita J.

description:
I walk by this place every morning on my way to work, and decided to try it out today.  Definitely different than a majority of Mexican restaraunts I've been to; instead of sitting down, it was more like cafeteria style.  Not bad, just different.  

I ordered two soft tacos, one carne asada, one shrimp, and a small side of black beans.  The carne asada wasn't spectacularly seasoned, the veggies in the shrimp taco were a little bland, and the beans weren't fully cooked. 

The staff was super nice though, so I bumped up what was probably a 2star experience to 3.  If you're in a rush and want something fast, I'd recommend Caramba, otherwise, be on the lookout for another Mexican place downtown.
author: ashley B.

description:
I have worked across the street from this place for over 6 months & finally got around to trying their food this week. What took me so long? Maybe it's the name of the place. It makes me think of Bart Simpson's favorite line "Ay Caramba!" 

On the advice of my fellow Yelpers I got the spicy chicken super burrito. It's not really spicy, but oh the flavor! The chicken must be slow cooked (it's nice & tender) with a bunch a green chilies. It makes kind of a soupy mess in the burrito but it tastes delicious. I love the option of getting a whole wheat tortilla too. The burrito makers are quick & efficient & I was in & out of there in a matter of minutes, right in the middle of the lunch rush. 

I'll be back to try their chile verde super burrito, which will most likely be a drippy mess too but I'm up for it.
author: Erin S.

description:
If this place didn't deserve 5 stars for anything else, it certainly does for this one fact: they will make you a colorado style breakfast burrito.

Where I'm from, Colorado, breakfast burritos are bacon, egg, cheese and potato.  No rice, no beans.  Many other taquerias I've been to in SF, even wonderful ones, come close but miss.  This place does it right.   *awesome*!
author: Daniel H.

description: Breakfast burrito of chorizo and eggs was AMAZING. It was pretty small, but for $3 I can't complain. Definitely going to be my go-to for Mexican food in SoMa.
author: T M.

description:
Everything is great ! My favorite is the shrimp burrito.Get the chips too, they are definitely better than Chipotle.
I will keep coming back, even if it means a time consuming walk from my office.
author: P D.

description:
Excellent sized authentic burritos and great portions. Decently priced and definitely beats a large Mexican food chain that I won't mention. Coming here for lunch, I had the carne asada burrito, which was delicious!!! Their menu also includes a breakfast menu which also looked mouthwatering with different sides to add at your liking. 

There is only street parking as like any restaurant in the city. There is plenty of dining area here though enough for a group of buddies from the office to have lunch.

You know this place is authentic when they offer "horchata" as a drink -- this is one of my favorite drinks. If I'm in the area, this will be another place I'll have to stop by.

Hey .... they also take credit cards here too.
author: Robb J.

description:
I got a grilled chicken quesadilla. It was very good, huge quesadilla and very tasty for only $5.80.
The place had a line but the the service was quick. Will be going there again!
author: Paulo C.

description:
I have been eating lots of Mexican, that could explain the additional weight gain on my scale.  

My coworker brought a Torta back to the office and raved about how good it was.  I love tortas! I haven't had one since college, off the taco trucks.  I rounded up my fellow team members during lunch and got TAKE OUT! 

The torta came with meat, cheese, tomatoes, lettuce, jalepeno's and avocado.  It was warm on top of dutch crutch,. SO GOOD and only $7.

Guess what else they have?! 

CARNE ASADA FRIES,. yes,. everything in a burrito,. but on FRENCH FRIES! 

It was delicious,. really heavy and greasy.. it was drenched with guacamole and sour cream.  I felt a heart attack with each bite. One thing I would recommend is to have them fry the fries longer, so they don't get soggy underneath! 

I will def be back for lunch,. :)
author: Chanel L.

description: Terrible customer service. Attitude because I asked for a breakfast burrito and it was 10:38, 8minutes after their breakfast time ended. They might have good food, but I didn't stick around to be mistreated as a customer.
author: Steven L.

description: They don't have the "taqueria" smell.  Like the salsa bar.  Burrito is ok but too "loose" so it falls apart very easily as you eat so best to put on a plate and eat with knife and fork, which takes away the joy of eating a burrito.
author: Gloria H.

description:
I'm best friends with the super burrito. Get it with spicy chicken, spicy salsa and everything else. Yummy.

Also, free horchata on Fridays!
author: Ben C.

description:
It sounds like most of the reviews here are for their breakfast offerings, I went for lunch.

When I first walked in, I had my reservations due to the lack of diversity.  Then I finished my meal and can confirm that this place is perfect for Caucasian people.  Please don't take offense to that, all I'm trying to say is Caramba exemplifies the following:

-Very high level of cleanliness
-Easy to read, big boards
-Staff that is 100% fluent in English
-Detailed descriptions for type of meat, type of dish (enchiladas, tortas, etc.)

^^^ I've noticed a trend of yelp reviewers who use these categories as the main basis for their reviews of Mexican food.  These are of minimal importance to me, when did people start to hate hole-in-the-walls so much?

The quality of food and selection is decent, but I give it 3 stars because honestly, it's just not my style of Mexican cuisine.  95% of the people here during lunch ordered the most generic thing ever : Carne Asada Super Burrito.  Even more surprising with offerings like Barbacoa on the menu....

I ordered the Chicken Mole super burrito with no rice, just as I do at every other Mexican place I go to in SF.  I'm guessing the guy wasn't used to this request (but handled other requests perfectly like sub rice for lettuce, no sour cream but extra sauce, etc.) because the moment I started to eat my burrito, everything fell out right away.  They re-made it immediately, and the 2nd time around it was wrapped properly. 

The ingredients were undeniably fresh, but the burrito was very bland, even though I asked for him to make it spicy.  Unfortunately, I've become accustomed to this.  So many people with weak tolerances for spice will ask that their burrito be made "very spicy".  After enough customers in this category visit a place (happens very quickly), this understandably causes restaurants to not fulfill that request (make it spicy) to the fullest extent (throw some salty jalapenos on it instead).  So when a person who actually wants a spicy burrito (me!) asks for something to be made spicy, they are left very unsatisfied.  It's kind of like that scene in Parks and Recreation when Ron Swanson asks the diner for all the bacon and eggs they have, and he has to say it again to them to make sure they truly got the message and meaning of his statement.

My normal workaround for this is to ask for habaneros, but of course, due to the crowd this place caters to (reiterating that there is nothing wrong with that, they are simply adapting for the best interests of their business), they did not have any.

So to sum up, if you're the kind of person who gave El Faro a horrible yelp review because it wasn't clean enough for you, the burrito didn't have enough sour cream, or you're mad that chips weren't free, Caramba is perfect for you!
author: Aalok P.

description:
Tired of the usual places for lunch in the area I decided to give Caramba a try.

There are tons of sandwich places, and the usual lunch line at Chipotle so why not try the unknown restaurant with no line? Ok, so it could have been a recipe for disaster, but it wasn't.

Fries! I can't believe that most taquerias still don't have a carne asada fries option or a french fries in the burrito. I suppose my preference for this comes from my years in southern california. Caramba to the rescue!

I had some carne asada fries and I was not disappointed. Service can be a bit slow in preparation, but nothing compared to the long lines at the other options for lunch.  Since I am selfish, I'm glad this place is relatively unknown, keeps the lines short (or maybe I just get lucky when I come here. Either way, I'll take it)
author: Glenn M.

description: Amazing Mexican food. Seriously the best in San Francisco! I go there at least twice a week. Great service as well
author: Maurice A.

description:
Food: A - Had an excellent prawn burrito, fresh, made to order; salsa bar is a thoughtful way to help enhance food to individual tastes
Price: B+ - not cheap, but reasonable
Atmosphere: C - it is what it is - "hole in the wall" - it's not Chipotle, so take out was my preference, but they have places to sit
Service: A - Very friendly, helpful, attentive
Menu: B+ - traditional quick Mexican food, wish they had soup

Overall B+ - fast, good quality, great service
author: JM H.

description:
What can I say...Mexican taqueria in finacial? 
I think it's as good as it gets in this neck of the woods. It's kind of sad because me and Mexican food is like flys to sh!t I just love the stuff! But it's my go to when I'm desperate enough and just can't fight the craving.
author: T L.

description:
Delicious ground beef crunchy tacos. Fresh food and prompt service. 
Perfect place for cheap Mexican food that is delicious. Ill definitely be back!!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
I've went to this place a while ago with work and it wasn't so good back then.  This time when I walked by there was a long line, so I figured I'd give it another try.  I dunno, it could have changed owners or something...
unfortunately I was wrong, it was still bad.

Prices are good for downtown, but the food was so bland.  I had a taco and enchilada plate and not a thing there excited me at all.  They used the microwave to make the enchilada (which is ok, because everyone does that now), but then I watched them pull my hard taco out of a safeway box.  I dunno, I was just expecting more.  Don't worry though, I'll probably be suckered into stopping by this place another time in a couple years.
author: Brian G.

description: Living in the Mission has spoiled me when it comes to Mexican food. Finding an awesome hole-in-the-wall taqueria in the FIDI = WIN.
author: Amber B.

description:
I met my bff at Henry's today for lunch and they were closed. We opted for the next restaurant closest by...which was Caramba. 

I got the Banderilla-chicken skewers, which came with rice and salad, Jen got the veggie quesadilla, and we split the menudo...that's right..tripe soup for lunch. 

The menudo was actually pretty good..but the chicken skewers was not good at all. It was too charcoaled on the outside and tasteless inside :(
I think next time I will stick with something safer..a burrito or taco.
author: Mimi T.

description:
I can't believe I've worked in SOMA for all these years without me ever stepping foot into Caramba.  Well, popped my cherry today, thanks to Yelp!

Caramba quesadilla (spinach, mushroom and cheese) on spinach tortilla.  Side of sour cream (I'm bad, I know...).  Side of salsa.

So tasty.  So filling.  Food coma, now.

Total damage: $5.37
author: Jenny L.

description: Imagine traveling to an unfamiliar city. You arrive at 11pm, when all restaurants and most stores are closed. One store is open, and you grab a can of beans, a jar of salsa, and a bag of chips to take back to the hotel. You microwave the beans in a paper cup. You use the coffee utensils in your hotel room to eat. The chips are yellow and crunchy, but flavorless. The salsa has tomatoes in it, but is otherwise unremarkable. Yes, you will survive, but you will try harder tomorrow to find a real place to eat.
author: Brett N.

description: I ordered the 3 chicken taquitos plate (#4 on the menu). It comes with beans and rice and the taquitos were topped with sour cream, guacamole and salsa on a small bed of lettuce. The cashier asked spicy or mild? I said spicy but it was not spicy at all.. so you need to take advantage of the hot sauce bar to spice it up. The taquitos were STUFFED with a whole lot of chicken meat, but the meat did not have any flavor. It was an OK place. Good for lunch. There's plenty of room inside to sit and eat.
author: Kathy N.

description: Real good Mexican food. Reasonable prices.
author: Gabriel D.

description:
Hard to find authentic taquera-style food in the Financial District, at least the area where I work, so I'm glad for Caramba. I'm usually a big quesadilla fan and I enjoyed the one here quite a bit. It was under six dollars but extremely filling, and anyone who works in the FiDi knows what a rarity that is.

Another time I had a super burrito which was pretty good, and tried a friend's nacho fries, which hooooly crap, why didn't anybody think of that before / how deadly an idea is that. Bravo, Caramba. Cheap and delicious.
author: Dara K.

description:
A bunch of my co-workers used to go to this place quite frequently for breakfast but we've not really had the chance to do that lately. I, being prone to eating early, wasn't ever in a position to join them so I can't comment on the breakfast except for their freakish (kidding) love for this place (or at the very least for the breakfast plates or burritos).

I had the shrimp tacos recently and I loved the way they were prepared. Sure the tortilla was a bit bland but it's a tortilla -- the true goodness was the spicy shrimp with bell peppers. Oh and their horachata is a bit on the creamy side which means it's delicious.
author: Shauna S.

description:
(1) fried chicken chimichanga
(2) shrimp burritos 

Highly recommend both... although after either of those during your lunch hours, it will put you into major food coma for sure!!!

Decently priced - around $7-8 dollars, which isn't too bad for being in SOMA financial district area.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Back in the day, both Caramba here and Rico Mex on Stevenson used to be called 'Si Senor.'   While the names have changed, I think it's still the same owners...   Well, at least I recognized the cashier at Caramba.

I got the 3 taquitos especial to go, which basically means that some dude heads out back and throws a couple of frozen taquitos into the deep-fryer...  Some couple of minutes later, he comes back and they ask you what kind of beans you want...  I highly recommend the refried beans, a great choice for plenty of afternoon flatulence.   Of course, it being the especial, they'll ask you if you want guacomole and sour cream.   "Yes, plenty of both," should be your reply.   Might I suggest that you also ask for spicy salsa spread over the whole thing?   So they hand me this to-go box, I pay my $8  (includes a soda), and I head back to my office to eat in front of my computer.   

What'd I think?

Baaahhh...  While it was certainly not bad, it wasn't good either... I think Rico Mex is at least as good as this place, and they're closer to my work.   Don't expect to see me at Caramba much... That said, it's solid Mexican food... assuming of course you're never spent a long amount of time in Southern California or, better yet, Mexico... in which case you'll think this food sucks donkey balls.    Of course, if you're a European who's spent all his life in Stockholm and just moved to SF 2 or 3 years ago, you'll probably think this stuff is the best Mexican food you've ever tasted.... and you'd probably be right.
author: David O.

description:
The burritos are very good here, better than Chipotle for sure. Each time get a burrito here, I tell myself that I won't eat the whole thing, then devour it within 15 minutes. Food coma!

Love it here.. service is very fast as well.
author: Neal P.

description: Decent shrimp burrito and Chile relleno burrito. I've had better around there. Avoid the ghetto looking nachos though. No bueno! I'd come back for the shrimp tacos though ;)
author: Oskar D.

description:
I ordered the bacon and egg breakfast burrito. It looked too skinny, but it was quite filling. I actually kind of liked it small because I could actually bite into the burrito without it falling all over the place.

This place was decent for being under $3. I was surprise that it was busy in the morning. I enjoyed sitting inside and looking at the nice art decor on the walls.

If you want to use a credit card, I believe they charge you an additional $.40 or else make sure you have cash on hand!
author: CeCe C.

description: They have a great breakfast burrito and decent nachos but I haven't really liked anything else on the menu. They have a lot of different salsas to choose from which is super cool. The staff is nice but the place can be quite a zoo at times because there is so much chaos going on and nobody knows when it's their turn to order or pay. They need to really get some kind of better system in place. I like going in the mornings when it's slow because there are a lot of tables to sit at and enjoy your morning burrito.
author: Dusty N.

description: Super tasty, moist burritos -- I think it's the saucy black beans -- at a really affordable price for the area. So glad to have such a great taqueria by work!
author: Midori S.

description: Most of the food in SOMA/FiDi area is over priced and not very good with the exception of Caramba. It is exactly what you want when you want authentic mexican food. The breakfast burritos I might even go as far as to say are the best I have had in the city. Simple and delicious and possibly the best hangover cure ever. I have had burritos, tacos, enchiladas, and the taco salad all delicious! Also, the women who work here are super nice. I would highly recommend this place.
author: Sophie J.

description:
Meh... so much MEH.

I ordered a super vegetarian burrito, just under $6. It was filled with cold, mushy MEH. My tummy is mumbling insults as I type this... 

There are so many lunch options in SOMA. Pass on this one.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
$6 for a regular burrito, which pretty much includes beans, rice, cheese, salsa, and your choice of meat. They have extra salsa in a little cart. Oh, and they have diff. wraps as well -- wheat, flour, spinach! I liked having that option, as most Mexican places do not offer that.

With that said, the burrito tasted really good once it was out of the foiled wrap. However, after several bites, I can taste all the calories, and it was just dunzo from there. 

I feel like I could go to Chipotle and get more, or one of those bombass places back in SoCal (: Still on the search for a delicious, cheap Mexican place...
author: Evelyn S.

description:
Really good tostada salad and taquitos! I like their generous selections for meats, beans and salsas. 
This is the best mexican food I've found in the city. The prices are VERY reasonable.
author: Stephenie P.

description:
Great Mexican food and affordable for SOMA.  There is no reason to go anywhere else (El Faro, Chipotle, Baja not-so-fresh)

Carne Asada and El Pastor are great, the Mole is surprisingly good, chips are decent, maybe a little salty and yes, they have a respectable salsa bar. 

Oh...the line moves surprisingly fast..
author: Mike V.

description:
I wish these guys knew how to wrap a burrito properly.  I mean, their flavor is decent, but every 4th or 5th time I get a burrito here, it comes out as a big watery mess.  I'm looking at today's version right now and it is quite literally sitting in a puddle on my plate.

Overall I keep coming back because it's nearby the office and reasonably tasty, but there you have it.
author: Geoff D.

description:
¡Ay, caramba!

I miss you. Friday mornings used to be our time. After nights like last night (where I may or may not have been sitting next to a girl in a Yeti hat and I may or may not have been wearing deer antlers...at Delirium) I would wake up knowing I could fight the day after taking down a Caramba Combo. Bacon, eggs, cheese, bell pepers, onions, no pico...tear.

The women there in the morning are so sweet. They would always remember me and my order. Currently I remain the Duchess, but I'm sure Ned L. will eventually dethrone me. 

Until next time Caramba.

xoxo
author: Leah B.

description: These are the best breakfast burritos I have ever had!  There is so much flavor throughout the entire burrito.  I wish I lived in town so that I could get them all the time. The staff is so friendly as well!
author: Allison G.

description: This place sorta deserves five stars for what it is: a traditional taqueria but here, in the financial district! How awesome is that? Where else can you get tasty al pastor tacos that aren't served up like a gourmet attraction for $12 a plate? Too bad they aren't open  for dinner. Service is good, food is good, prices are good. Solid four stars. But what really makes this place is that it's close to work and isn't some foofy foody financial commitment. Mmm. My mouth's watering just thinking about those tacos.
author: david b.

description:
Very disappointed with my lunch today at Caramba.

I got a Tostadas (flat hard shell tortilla) with chicken, black pinto beans, guacamole and lettuce. The guacamole was okay, the chicken was not the leanest I've ever tried and the tortilla itself was not the kind of tortilla I was used to get when I'm ordering a Tostadada (usually they are golden and cripy, and mine was white/floury and I can say it was crispy).
And last but not least I got charged almost $8 for something that was priced at a bit more than $5 on their menu. This is really disappointing :-(

According to other review I read after getting there, this might not have been my lucky day. However since the only thing that was great was to hang out with friends there, next time I will try another restaurant in this area. I won't miss Caramba as I can definitely find much better deal for mexican food in the Mission/Noe Valley.
author: Cedric L.

description: Good breakfast burritos. Service is solid. Price is right.  Lines are short early in the mornings but back up at times around 830.
author: James C.

description:
The best Chili Verde burritos I've found in the city.!! The pork is succulent and ooooses with tasty goodness. 

I use to work around the corner and would frequent Caramba religiously. Since our office moved a year ago, I find myself daydreaming about the Chili Verde every so often. Sometimes we'll even make the trek and pickup orders for the entire company, it's that good.
author: Maggie L.

description: The chorizo and egg burrito is very good! Definitely add papas.
author: John M.

description:
¡Ay caramba! This place is great.  Line out the door, but moves very fast.  The nacho fries are an orgasm of flavor in your mouth. Everyone in my office insisted on trying them even though I did not offer.  

Soft tacos were a bust.  I won't order these from here again, although the carnitas meat was pretty good.  The burritos everyone else was eating looked great though.  Will definitely be back.  Get the carne asada in whatever you order. So much flavor!

Happy Cinco de Mayo!
author: Jordan F.

description: I got the California burrito. It was good, but not anything to write home about. The line was short, though, so it is a nice alternative to have handy.
author: Chris V.

description:
Come here often for breakfast. Its open very early so thats a +

Breakfast burrito with chorizo and eggs, potato, rice, cheese and hot salsa. I feel like its a bit on the expensive side but who cares?

For lunch, carne asada super burrito, or a carne asada california burrito are good choices too.
author: Richard P.

description:
As I started to write my review...I just realized I never got my guac!!!

In my exploration of SoMa lunch eateries, I went to Caramba with a few co-workers.  It is the closest burrito shop to the office (for all of you purists, I'm not counting Chipotle), and I was fine with it.  They have a wide selection of meats (al pastor - always tasty, typically underrated) and an interesting sequential/parallel process burrito line.  It probably doesn't make sense, but if it looks as though people are cutting in front of you it's probably because there are actually two burrito stations behind the counter - one is ahead of the other...it's not a continuation of burrito station #1.  Anyway, my point is, they have standard fillings, standard service....standard place.

And for an additional $0.80 you can get guac...or find out you didn't actually get the guac when you return to the office (or when you write your Yelp review!).  I won't hold it against them - innocent mistake.  But be warned, check for your guac...
author: Wendy L.

description:
Decent Mexican food, conveniently located a block from my job. I've only had the sopes special, with carnitas and the works. The plate is decently priced for SOMA, 2 sopes for $5.90. The carnitas is good, hits the spot when you craving. Although last time I had it, it was a bit salty. The guacamole seems like it's blended instead of smashed and it was turning slightly brown. The good think is that they pack it on with beans, salsa, sour cream, guacamole and lettuce. However, beware, you will be full and lazy for your pm hours of work! Lol. 

I've heard that the taco truck on Sansome is better but i haven't been. Overall, I'll def be back.
author: Dora S.

description:
Ok.. i had another burrito here and I'm adding a stars on again.  I went with a carnitas burrito, and it deifnatly wasn't anythign to write home about, but I don't think they deserve 1.

Menu is really scary looking, with all these additions on pieces of paper.... food is mediocre, but the peopel working are really really nice....
author: Joseph F.

description: Love Caramba!! Great tasty tasty meat options (pastor!!! Nom non nom!) I love everything here from the nachos, burritos to even the breakfast burritos! The portions are always super generous and the staff are always super nice. They also make the breakfast burritos to order so no soggy/cold eggs! Now they even do these crazy nacho fries, super tasty but HUGE i would suggest if you and a friend are both super hungry then get these to share!
author: Dominique D.

description:
Caveats to this review:
- I only tried the breakfast
- I was really hungry.

Now we can continue.

I hail from the land of dry heat and Filibertos (Phoenix, Arizona), so when I woke up this morning with a hankering for A Bacon, Egg and Cheese burrito, I had a certain set of expectations. Unfortunately Caramba missed on most of them. When I entered the restaurant it seemed to fit the bill. Nothing flashy, a purposeful and thus authentic looking Mexican food shack. Then I saw the price of the Bacon and egg, $2.85. "Wow, thats cheap I thought". I should have known. When I received my burrito it was pitifully sized. Real burritos would have looked at this one, and told it to come back when it grows up. A good rule of thumb for a place like this. Your burrito should at least be bigger than what you would get at a taco bell. If you haven't figured it out yet, this thing was ridiculously small.  My phone was bigger. Think about that. 2nd ding was the tortilla. For a place to win on this, they have to use an authentic tortilla. This burrito was wrapped in something bought at the local supermarket and chocked full of preservatives. The salsa inside was tasty, Ill give them that (though not at all spicy, as advertised). 

I don't know, perhaps breakfast is not their strong suit. Maybe I should give them a try at lunch. But not unless they get some better tortillas.
author: Sean N.

description:
Caramba: I am as we speak fantasizing about your carne asada fries that I'm having for lunch tomorrow. I'll walk many blocks in the wind and traffic for those french fries swimming in cheese, steak, sour cream and guacamole that are so hard to find outside San Diego.

If you love Mexican, hot and fresh, with an extensive menu and right in the heart of the financial district, you'll love Caramba.
author: Alyssa G.

description: Caramba is the place to go for hangovers. And you better get a scrambled eggs chorizo burrito (add beans). One is good enough. It's great for take out, otherwise, they have many tables. This place is usually more full in the mornings and pretty empty the rest of the day. The location is great and the food is affordable. Where else in the area will you find a $2.88 breakfast burrito? No where, but Caramba!
author: Stephanie M.

description:
I went here twice in a week so we know I don't think its bad.. I actually liked the carnitas taco I had on Monday. Good flavor, reasonably priced, definitely not a bad thing.

I had the torta yesterday with carnitas and jalapenos, I didn't like it at all. It was bland. Which is amazing because usually carnitas on their own are good, but they weren't salty enough and it wasn't cooked well enough to have that lovely outside crisp that I enjoy. I'll probably go back again sometime when I forget my lunch again, so I'll give it three solid stars.
author: Analisa S.

description:
I was stuffed with 2 tacos (carne asada & carnitas) and a beer.

I thought the meat was pretty salty, but overall was flavorful. 

I would definitely recommend this place as a quick meal.
author: Anisha G.

description: When it's a cold dreary day out in SF, you're super hungry and having a bad day, and it's past lunch hour...a cheap, warm, and gigantic $6.60 super carne asada burrito is just the perfect solution.
author: Sally C.

description:
I went to Caramba on Monday morning for a breakfast burrito. I ordered a breakfast burrito with bacon and it seemed like it was already made (I dont know how long ago) because they took it from one container, put it in the pan to reheat it and done. :( Disappointed! Anyways I decided to give them another try. 

I went the next day and order a Popeye burrito which is an egg burrito with mushrooms and spinach. It seemed like they didnt put mushroom because they were cut into really really small pieces, I prefer bigger pieces so it can get more of a taste. 

Overall it was decent. The lady that works there in the morning was very friendly though, so they deserved a star for that. :)
author: Leslie M.

description: Speedy service and a tasty burrito make this an excellent lunch spot if  you are in a hurry. There is a decent amount of seating if you have time, but this Mexican restaurant shines more on the quality of the eats than the ambiance and the wide variety of salsas to choose from are the icing on the cake.
author: Steven G.

description:
This place should be called ¡Ay, caramba!  Apparently people who work too much downtown lose most of their taste buds and the ability to differentiate size.  

The food is bland and the portions are small.  For $7.00, I expect a super burrito to be SUPER!  Not so for caramba's super...  I would say its half the size of the super burrito from:

El Burrito Express 1 
(http://www.yelp.com/biz/el-burrito-express-1-san-francisco)

Don't listen to these 4/5 star reviews and save your money for McDonalds, at least you get your money's worth there.
author: Kailo R.

description: I frequent this place often and love it! Great breakfast burritos. I usually order the Caramba salad. Yum! Burritos are very filling too. Very friendly staff and quick service.
author: Kristin L.

description: I work around here and this is usually the spot I hit up when I want a burrito. Except every time I have lunch here, I usually get indigestion or heartburn. I know it's not Mexican food in general, since I never get this when I make it or eat elsewhere. The burrito isn't bad, but my tummy tends to hurt for hours afterwards. Anyone else experience this?
author: Jenn S.

description: Pretty good burrito, cheap, fast and super convenient. There are some places in the mission that are certainly better, but for SOMA Caramba is delicious.
author: Greg S.

description:
Absolutely terrible.  If I could rate 0 stars, this Caramba deserves it.  Ordered a combination fajita plate to get a feel of the restaurant's tastes... which were completely absent.

The carne asada, chicken, and shrimp were ALL overcooked.  Inedible.  If you don't mind burnt meat, you may enjoy this place.

The beans tasted smokey (smoked beans?), the rice was tasteless as was the meat.

Service is non-existent, and if you buy guacamole dip, be prepared to pay extra for chips to dip in it.  Speaking of which the guacamole is definately not homemade.

Save your money, I walked away hungry.
author: Loren S.

description: The burritos are very good, but they are not amazing. They are also realllllly small.  My friend got hers with avocado in it which looked bomb!  I go every few weeks and i will make it a  point to try it with the avocado and see if it makes  a difference.  Its a  great breakfast spot if you have a fix for a burrito.  The salsa bar is also wonderful.  he avocado based salsa is the best.
author: Tami G.

description:
copy and pasted from elsewhere because apparently I'm directionally challenged and suffering from short term memory issues and gave this review for another place that I've never been. *golfclap*

Short and sweet:
* awesome quesadillas, one of the best I've ever had (omg so much cheese)
* the tacos are *huge* (for tacos anyway)
* price is pretty flippin' awesome

Two forks up.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Came here for some breakfast the other day and got their veggie breakfast burrito (onions and peppers) with black beans (a little extra), overall was pretty fuilfilling! Service is fine, prices fairly cheap for the area, total came to about $5. Not bad at all! 

I usually hit up Cafe Venue on Montgomery for my breakfast burrito fixes, but liked that Caramba offered so many extras. Venue's great but I'd say its a smidge more expensive with less options. Both are awesome in their own ways.. but the veg plus black beans and hot sauce will put it over the top!
author: Tejal D.

description:
I'm from Southern California and I know my Mexican food.  This ain't it.  I really wish it was because it's close by to where I am all day and the Chipotle down the street is the stingiest, crappiest Chipotle in existence so I would love a reasonable alternative.

It's not terrible or anything, but it's definitely not very good either.  Everything I've had is bland and unexceptional.  Anyone who tells you it's amazing is probably from the midwest.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Chicken tacos were dry.
Carnitas tacos were mediocre.

Skip it.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
This restaurant illegally charges the customer a $.40 transaction fee for using a credit card. This is against California Penal Code and also against credit card vendor policies. 

Why should the customer pay for you to do business? 

The nickel and diming here is out of control. A bag of stale tortillla chips will coat you $1. Guacamole is extra, but check your burrito if you order it. I ordered it, paid for it, and found a small fleck of avocado in the entire burrito. 

I'm done with this place, their poor business practices and their mediocre food.  

Go to Tropisueno at Yerba Buena lane. Much better food and prices.
author: sparkle f.

description: Cool spot off Mission. Breakfast burritos are very delicious. The lunch time menu is ok.
author: Yonder B.

description: the new and updated menu features - drum roll please - super burritos de chille relleno - of course i cant pass this up and go to Caramba at lunch - only to be told - that they ran out of stuffed peppers. So props for expanding the menu. And thumbs down for bad planning.
author: Oleg H.

description: I tried this place 2 times.   I ordered a carnitas burrito and the 2nd time a steak burrito.   How can you screw up a burrito?  they did...  the black beans has no taste and were runny.    I even bought chips and salsa....  the chips had no salt and the salsa was greasy tasting and no flavor?  no spice what so ever. Who screws up salsa?????  not too mention when you walk into this place,  you do smell the nastiness of the floor.    Not a clean sign.    anywho I tried this place twice,  and never again.   disgusting!!!!!
author: Jerry P.

description:
Average Mexican joint. The chicken burrito was good. 

Chips do not come with the burritos. They do have a salsa bar though.

Ehhh. I wouldn't go out of my way to go here again.
author: Chili B.

description:
This place looked sketchy the moment I walked in.  So I saw a sign outside showing, FREE coffee, water, or tea with purchase of breakfeast burrito $3.75+.  I go inside, ordered a bacon and cheese, with cheese (add another 70 cents) total cost of a breakfeast burrito $3.80.  So I asked, "Does this come with tea?".  The lady's reply "No. That is only on Wednesday and Friday".  I replied back but the sign says breakfast menu and it does not have specifc dates listed.  Then she said, "Oh that is for lunch only".  I was thinking why would you have a breakfeast menu for lunch?  Then she asked another co-worker and they said something in Spanish and laughed it off.  

The breakfeast burrito tasted nasty anyways. YUCK!
author: Elliot Y.

description:
It hurts me to give Caramba 2 stars since I've had so many good burritos here over the years, but it's justified by the fact that those burritos and the burritos they now serve are not the same thing. It's already a little pricey and small for what it is, but their carnitas was really really good and, most importantly for me anyway, didn't have any fat or bone or cartilidge in it. 

Not anymore. 

I had a burrito that was delicious until "crunch!!" and then "squishhhh". If you're like me these are truly horrifying sensations when eating meat. I chalked it up to an anomaly and tried it again and got a good burrito. Yay!! Then yesterday, crunch, squish, ..... BLECH!!!! Sorry Caramba, you made a decision to save a few cents on carnitas by not trimming it and you lost my business. Hope it was worth it.
author: jeremy m.

description:
"Cheese, I need more cheese!?!?!?!"

So today, I was craving something somewhat healthy, but with a little more ummpf than a salad and so I searched Yelp mobile and found Caramba. Cool, I can do watered down tacos. And so I hobbled (new heels, gotta love em) down the street to Caramba and checked out the menu on the wall. Ahead of me was a couple, (who please God noooooo, don't let them actually be together or having f'ugly people sex as that visual may scar me for life), who couldn't decide what to order.

I wasn't on a super tight time constraint or anything, but c'mon, it's Mexican food, it's the same 7 ingredients served multiple ways, so pick a presentation and let's motor already. After about 4 minutes (no, I'm not exaggerating), they settled on burritos. Hallelujah! But now they needed to talk the little lady behind the counter through it. Here we go.

As soon as she grabbed the flour tortilla, this broad was 8 steps ahead of her and asking for cheese. And not in the, "Hey, I will be wanting cheese at some point, cuz boy howdy do I love me some cheese" way, but in a super frazzled, amazingly panicked, the world is about to run out of cheese in the next 10 seconds!?!? tone. Jeez lady, calm down. 

As she went down the line, she reminded the gal that she needed extra cheese. Yes, we got it lady, the whole restaurant is with ya, you will get your cheese. As soon as the thing was bursting at its cheesy seams (the burrito, not the broad, although she didn't look like much of a stranger to the effects of cheese, if ya know what's sayin') it was time for her to choose a beverage. Oh Lord, here we go!

Broad: "Do I like the Negro Modelo?"
Annoyed Male Friend: "I don't know, do you?"
Broad: "Well I don't remember? Will it go with my burrito? Is it a Mexican?"
Over it Male Friend: "I don't know, probably"
Broad: Well should I get the...what is this, the horchaaataaaa drink?"
My New Hero Male Friend: "Who cares, just pick something!?"

Man, I love people. Oh, and my two plain tacos were tasty.
author: Stephy S.

description:
So... I know I promised an update, and it's a little long in coming (because I haven't been in town in months) but I finally made it back to round out my review of this joint... and dragged along some friends!

The verdict is that I committed a complete and utter SNAFU the last time I picked up a b'fast 'rito here.  Yes, the chorizo is awesome and savory.  Yes, the tortilla was just as soft and it held everything together just right.  But!  This time... I got more than just chorizo wrapped in tortilla.  And the outcome was magical.

Those "extras" that I didn't realize I needed to add to make a breakfast burrito a breakfast burrito last time (say... egg, cheese, and potatoes?) and hot salsa transformed a deliciously greasy and savory wrap into a steamy, filling, nose-sweat inducing, savory breakfast bounty... neatly wrapped in foil.  Y'know how bananas are kind of the perfect natural food wrapping?  Yeah, this foil was basically the equivalent of a banana peel.  Did that make sense to anyone but me?

I'm pretty sure the conclusion by others was pretty congruous to mine.  Mmmm.  And to think that I'm going back to the land devoid of good breakfast burritos.  Stab me in the face.
author: Kevin L.

description: $9.5 for a chile relleno and an agua fresca, taxes included. Very nice. The line is long, though, and the tortillas were a little too sticky.
author: Bruno N.

description:
What a delicious meal! Sauteed Chicken Super Burrito with oh so fresh and tasty rice, tender and flavorful meat and pretty decent guacamole. It was the perfect meal to rebuild calories lost to Lovefest for sure.

The prices aren't as cheap as some other Mexican places, but they were reasonable and they accept all credit cards. I had no issue with the service or the cleanliness for sure.
author: Ryan V.

description:
Note:  This place is called Caramba now.  Not Si Senior...and it is not closed cuz i ate here today!

Did you know.....
That all types of beans give you the same amount of gas? Thats what i found out when i first walked in to Caramba, and the woman in front of me asked that question.  I don't know if i believe that, but I'll take homeboys word for it.  After finding this out, she opted to get her burrito no beans.  Is that even a burrito anymore?

I got  the vegetarian supreme burrito...it was tasty.  I hope black beans are less gassy than the rest.  For your sake.
author: Lauren F.

description:
I'm not a big fan.  From the stern strictly business service to what I feel are largely bland burritos, it's hard to get excited about going here.  Guacamole costs extra and the amount that they is put on can best be described as a stingy smear.  The salsa bar is a plus...and unfortunately necessary to add some much-needed flavor to the burritos.

The tasty burrito drought near SF MOMA/Yerba Buena continues...hopefully a much needed burrito oasis will come to this area someday.
author: Steve B.

description:
To be fair, I'm not the biggest burrito lover out there.  And, I made the silly mistake of ordering the shrimp burrito here, where it soon became obvious that the shrimp had been languishing in their pool of ranchero sauce for an indecent amount of time.  I'll feel lucky if I don't get food poisoning because there was a tepid, bacteria-loving temperature to the shrimp and a mealiness that does not portend good things.  Other than that major drawback, I guess the burrito was okay.  I mean, it's hard to screw up a flour tortilla, right?  So let this serve as a warning: don't order the shrimp burrito.  

And I just want to take a moment here to express my love for soda that comes from Mexico.  God bless Mexican soda.  They use real sugar, not HFCS.  Mmmm . . . Jarritos mango soda . . .
author: Chalk A.

description:
This review is only for the breakfast burritos...  After a long hard night of drinking my body was craving some greasy food and when my co-worker suggested breakfast burritos I knew that was what I needed to get through the day.  On the outside this place looks kinda janky... I mean there's not even a sign that says Caramba, it just says Mexican Food...ignore this.   

I went a little overboard on my burrito and added pretty much every extra side available.  It started out as an egg and chorizo burrito...then I added potatoes...and cheese...and guacamole...and two salsas.   It was worth it though, my burrito was greasy and good and the combination of chorizo and potatoes was delicious.  Next time I would lay off the salsa in the burrito though, it just made things a little too watery.  And, for about $5 it's not a bad deal either.

It's not the best Mexican Food around, but in terms of Soma, it's pretty good and I'll be back for breakfast burritos.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Congrats, you piece of shit taqueria. You've managed to make 360 Degree Burritos look good. In between the wack-ass service, the carne asada that was oversalted to hide how long it was kicking it on the steam table, and terrible salsas, you reminded me why I never should get a burrito outside of the Mission. Worse than the burritos I've had in LA, and that's saying something.

I'm gonna go make myself throw up now, because I don't want you inside of me. Taqueria San Francisco -- expect me there, tonight.
author: Jake S.

description:
Yum.  They open at 7a and some days, I just needed that kick in the pants.  I'm no longer in the neighborhood for work, but there was many a morning when nothing but a bacon + egg burrito with hot sauce would do me right.  Even at 7a there would be people in line.  The woman who takes your (breakfast) order is the same who cooks the eggs on a tiny hot plate behind the register.  Bonus - you can watch them making the guac for the day while you wait for your breakfast burrito.
In all honesty, the tortilla is a bit gummy, but I scarf it down nonetheless and am ready for the day.
The two women who work mornings - always the same - are always pleasant and end it with a "have a good day!"
All this for like three bucks.
author: Meg W.

description:
I gave Caramba a try to day and it was pretty good. 
The line moves very fast, so you need to know what you want when you get up to the counter. I had the steak burrito w/ out beans  and a can of diet coke for $6.50, not bad!
My only complaint is they had REALLY loud music playing. I know, I sound like an old lady, but it was loud! One guy even got up and moved away from the speakers.

UPDATE 1/29/2007
Went back today for lunch and the music level was much better! Also happened to see a yelp crew of four walk in. Can't wait to see their review!
author: Lisa A.

description: This is my go to Mexican Food shop when I'm craving it and I'm at work.  Their stuff is kinda pricey, but it's not too bad.  I like coming here in the mornings for their breakfast burritos...they are so yummy and I like their Nachos for lunch time.  I prefer getting their Chicken instead of their Carne Asada.  I'm pretty picky when it comes to my carne asada cravings since i'm originally from San Diego and nothing beats the Carne Asada in SoCal.  This place has a pretty good menu.  It's definitely worth trying.
author: Leah A.

description:
It's my boss' favorite near-work restaurant, so I don't have much of a choice about this one.  It's your run-of-the-mill, average burrito shop, one of very few in SOMA.

But, despite my occasional transgressions, this place does not deserve to be patronized.  Si Senor is the restaurant that paid illegal immigrants less than minimum wage, then retaliated against them when they tried to claim restitution (here's the Chron article: http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2006/05/11/MNGR8IPK9E1.DTL ) .

The liberal guilt factor is not worth their mediocre (and occasionally soggy) burritos.
author: Sharon M.

description: I go here about once every two weeks or so. Its convenient to the were i work and its cheap! It taste pretty good too. I usually order a vegetarian burrito with cheese, rice, sour cream, guac, and beans. You can also choose your choice of wrap. They have flour, wheat, and spinach. The line always moves super quick, and you can usually find easy in door seating. Overall this place is satisfying for lunch.
author: V I P.

description: Great spot for a quick lunch to go! The burritos have the perfect ratio of ingredients and the meat is always flavorful. The line often stretches out the door but they move really fast.
author: Neil R.

description: Staff was friendly and fast. I went there for a breakfast burrito, which I felt was small for the price (~$5). The burrito was "just okay"... Potatoes were mushy; the "hot" salsa was mild; the eggs were a bit grainy. I'd go somewhere else before going again.
author: Levi B.

description: Good solid authentic burros and Mexican food for a quick stop on lunch.
author: Jase O.

description:
Ok, so, I'm not getting all the positive reviews for the Breakfast Burritos.  I ordered a simple Chorizo & Egg Burrito with potatoes and cheese.  Service was very scattered, they couldn't figure out whose order to take, but my burrito was made pretty quickly, though the joint was empty at 9 a.m.  

On to the burrito....my first impression.... "Man that sucker's tiny!"  Like itty bitty.  I know it's breakfast, and I know it's the financial district, but I could have gotten a bigger burrito at McDonalds.  And it came to over $4 dollars.  The chorizo wasn't too plentiful and cooked directly into the eggs.  I counted about 4 small chunks of potato, which I paid an extra $.80 for.  A decent sprinkling of cheese, albeit flavorless cheese, but it was there and only $.06 extra.  Couldn't find the salsa in there, thankfully I brought some back with me from their salsa bar.

All in all...below average and disappointing.  Toall the reviewers that raved about the breakfast burritos:  Seriously guys, get out to the Mission once in awhile.
author: Yolanda B.

description:
Why can't anyone in the Fidi/SOMA area make a decent burrito?!  
Went here today for lunch hoping to find something better than Chipotle or Il Faro.  I hate to say this, but Chipotle is better.  The veggie burrito w/guac that I ordered was bland and just icky.  There's some kind of weird black-magic synergy between the rice, beans, etc that makes a burrito good.  This place doesn't have that.  Furthermore, their ordering system (or lack thereof) is annoying.  The people taking orders mixed mine up with the guy standing next to me and spent the next several moments trying to figure out who got the plain tortilla (me) and who got the sun-dried tomato tortilla (him). One star for having an okay salsa bar, and one star for being close to work.
author: Michelle A.

description:
This review  is only for the breakfast burritos.  I work within a few feet of Caramba and I used to stop by in the morning because they have cheap and good breakfast burritos. They are small and if you get just the ham and egg, they're pretty healthy.  I used to love them.

What changed?  The OIL.  They started using so much oil that when you unwrap the foil it actually drips out all over your hands and desk.  I've asked them the last two times to not use oil (or at least use a very small amount) and still, absolutely dripping.

I've given up.  I may still go in for the veggie tacos on lunch, since they don't drown those in oil.  But no more breakfast burritos for me.  Bummer.
author: Jessica B.

description:
French fries in a burrito are good.
it's not my favorite mexican restaurant by any stretch, but for something different and just plain bad for you, it works.
author: Nedra D.

description: I go here fairly regularly for lunch.  The food is decent.  Not great, not horrible.  They're pretty quick with getting your food prepared.  However, there have been a couple of times when they're extremely busy (which is often) that they've messed up part of my order - wrong type of beans, salsa, etc.  You'll see other people in line correcting them with what they're doing.  Be attentive to get what you want.
author: Rob M.

description:
My fiance found these reviews and suggested we go to lunch. So we did and it was suggested (by these reviews) that before you die, you need to have their carnitas burritos.

Seriously, when in between beans, rice, cheese sour cream, guac and tortilla, you get a delicious mouthful of perfectly shredded almost grilled flavor of pork in your mouth, you have totally hit a winner. I've never really been impressed with carnitas before, but this truly showed me the love, flavor and goodness of what carnitas can be. 

I'm very eager to try their other burritos and I would highly suggest trying this place. When we went at lunch time, the place was packed, but the line moved incredibly fast and it wasn't hard to find seating. 

Go. Treat yourself to some burrito loving.
author: Jacqi M.

description:
Good food and cheap prices.  The menu is basic, but good.  I like the Carne Asada platter which comes with tortillas, rice and beans.  There's also a salsa bar.  Their breakfast burritos are good as well.

The seating area is not exactly upscale, but I can live with that.  They are open for breakfast and lunch, but not for dinner.  They are open only on weekdays.
author: hoo d.

description:
Okay, look. Here's the deal. All I've ever had here was a super veggie burrito. But I've had it a bunch of times. And it's perfect. Rice that stays out of the way, really good guac, packed with black beans and sour cream. What more do you want out of life?

They accept credit/debit. Take that Farolito.

If your main complaint is that your burrito isn't big enough, learn to eat less. Yea, it's more expensive than it should be, but it's 2nd/Mission. Good luck finding something that isn't.
author: jared c.

description:
What can I say?  I'm suffering sour cream withdrawal after the incident at Chipotle where the burrito wrapperess' Engrish trumped my Engrish.

The usual suspects: Lou, Tori and I.  

I asked for a Carnitas burrito with sour cream (it would cure the tremors that I'm suffering).  It was decent enough.  They charge $1 for the sour cream though.  I'm not digging that too much.  After all, the only money that grows on trees is also the tree that sprouts stem cell research openly, freely and with morality intact.  Ah, that's too much credit, it was only a burrito.

Can you guess what Tori got?  Yes, yes she did.  The chicken burrito with guacamole.  Predictable, in that good way, in the way one comes to appreciate, like the bus always arriving in the morning.

Lou also got a Carnitas Burrito.  Nom nom nom.

The Carnitas here was pretty darn salty.  And although I really like my salt, my lips are still chapped from this experience.  it was like I trekked through the darkest Tibet, wind-blown like Brad Pitt, but ever so much more swarthy.  The skin, it peels away from my lips, tender, gently I lick them, and then they crack like a fragile month old egg that has been neglected in the corner by a scrabbled brained bird-mommy.  My lips are still chapped, a good week after this incident.

The two star advantage here, the thing that will make me come back and beg on my bruised little knees: FREE HORCHATA and hot sauce so spicy, my SCALP TINGLED!  

Do you know how long it's been since anything excited me to the point where my scalp tingled?  Not since that Tiajuana winter, not since Pedro was traded to the Yankees, not since I started using Head and Shoulders Sensitive Skin Shampoo has my scalp tingled.  Ah, the memories, fondly, of youth.  

Free horchata and hot sauce that makes my skin crawl up and down my spine.

Only bad thing is that this place is also open crazy stupid FiDi hours.  Like 7am to 2:30 or something really really odd.
author: Christina C.

description: Love, LOVE the burritos here. I always get the same thing: A veggie super burrito with lettuce covered in enchalada sauce. It's always perfect and delicious. They have yummy pico and chips too. Their prices are great and the staff is friendly. Great lunch spot!
author: J D.

description:
For my first day of training at Learn IT, I ventured over to Caramba to test their burrito mettle against my tried and true North Bay favorites.  The price was right, the portions were a touch small for my liking.  Generally I like to be busting out of my pants after eating a big lunch, but the portions should be sufficient for those of you with sound judgement.

What can I say? I recommend asking them to put a bit of mild salsa, and a bit of the hot.  Mild is too weak, and the hot is pretty effing hot, so the mix is perfect.  A regular burrito will run you just under $6 after tax which is a bargain almost on any metric.

A regular burrito comes with the industry standard meat, beans, rice, salsa.  The downside to my experience was that the carne asada I had was dry and too salty for my liking.  The price is right, but perhaps a different meat choice would push this place to 4 star status.  Still, a great place to go if you are on a budget.

As with most places, it's best to beat the lunchtime rush, I came in around 11:45 and didn't have a problem getting a seat. It's a real short walk from 33 New Montgomery, under 5 mins.
author: Eric L.

description: Service was quick and the people were friendly. I wouldn't say it is among the best food I have ever had at a taqueria. It was the closes one to work during my lunch break.  I had the chicken fajitas and chips. The fajitas don't come out sizzling hot on a pan like you would see at other mexican restaurants but it was adequate for my hungry stomach. Their salsas were freshly made and the corn tortillas were warm. Their prices are definately reasonable so it is worth going  back to...especially when your stomach is growling.
author: Mike L.

description:
I come here at least once a week for lunch because I have a serious hankering for Mexican frequently. I really love the carnitas here. They're a bit salty so if salt isn't your thing, this may not be either. The burritos here are large and packed with goodness. You get your choice of beans, choice of meat, choice of hot or mild salsa, they will ask you if you want cheese, guac or sour cream. I always ask for some cilantro inside mine and they always oblige. The good part is that it's inexpensive! Great lunch choice for the budget conscious.

Oh, and before I forget to mention it, I've been here a few times for breakfast too. The egg, potato and chorizo breakfast burrito is also off the hook! 

In summation, I LOVE THIS PLACE! Awesome food for cheap = happiness!
Oh, and
author: Amy B.

description:
No Senor, I don't like to pay extra for a small bag of chips.  Can't you just throw a handful on my plate?

I had the enchilada plate with rice & beans--one enchilada with chicken, the other with ground beef.  The chicken was fine, apparently shredded (not chunks), but not very tasty.  The ground beef was better, and made the enchilada taste...better.  The enchilada sauce was the standard red routine, not especially tasty and nowhere near the enchilada sauce perfection of Casa Mexicana I.  Rice and beans were fine, but again, nothing special.

Decent enough fare, and reasonably priced, but nothing to write home about.
author: John D.

description:
My new favorite mexican restaurant.  The food is authentic mexican and very delicious.  Out of all the mexican joints in the bay area, they have the best customer service by far.  They are very friendly and are very generous with the toppings and the food in general.

I recommend the vegetarian burrito w/ enchilada sauce.  You get a huge burrito with rice, beans, cheese and salsa for under $5.
author: Mack D.

description:
Too heavy on the vegetable oil and the pinto beans didnt even have enough salt. Not the cleanest place. 
I came by before 7am and got breakfast here. They were scooping guacamole (?) out of a bucket with no gloves and using a steel bowl. No hairnet, just really down home.
If a server is sick or has sniffles there are NO precautions.
author: Nan L.

description: Another great spot downtown to head to for lunch. I got a delicious (and large) carnitas burrito (about $5-6). Their salsa bar has a great guacamole salsa and a spicy habanero sauce. My mouth was pretty much on fire, and yes, I ate the whole thing! Next time I want a great burrito I know where I will going!
author: Casi C.

description:
Best Breakfast burrito in the city! Also think the Salsa Verde is the best I have ever had. It is not available for breakfast, they only put it out for lunch. But Oh LA LA - do I love it. 

Meats can be a bit salty and suspect but everything else is very fresh. My staples are the veggie breakfast burrito (eggs, peppers and onions) and the veggie taco for lunch. I go there about 2-3 times a week.
author: Sarah P.

description: Not sure what the fascination is with this place. There's a crazy-ass line out the door at lunch time. Got a pretty tasty burrito here because I waited until 2pm, and there was no one in the place then. Cost me over $7. I think I'll stick with Chipotle if I'm gonna spend that much money, because the burritos are much bigger. I'll probably be back if I end up around there after the lunch mob dies down.
author: Mike T.

description: Note: they changed the name of their ever popular "Si Senor" breakfast burrito to "The Caramba." I get it with chorizo, and it's absolutely amazing. Best breakfast burrito in SOMA and I guarantee there are at least 9 employees from my office that will be ordering these on any given weekday.
author: Brianna H.

description:
Lauren S is right -- this place is alive & kickin', but under a diff'rent name: Caramba.

Chicken burrito was standard. Pretty good, but I wouldn't advise anyone to make an effort to come here unless they needed a lunchtime burrito within a one-to-two block radius of their work.

Caramba is just a'ight.
author: Pete J.

description: Not the best buritto in town but not the worst. These guys are basically consistent and fast. Not as fast as Chipotle but not as tasteless either. So it balances out. I usually come here when there is a line at Sentinel and I don't feel like walking to Los Compadres Taco Truck.
author: Greg G.

description: Lunch. Burrito. Salsa Bar. Quick. Seemingly healthy. Less than $5 with tax. Hooray.
author: Nikhil N.

description: i just love this place for two items only: either the carnitas, or al pastor (delicious) burritos. AND the breakfast burritos.  The BK Burritos are delicious and Cheap 2.75.  It comes with potatos which makes them so much better.  They are my go to shack when im downtown!!!!!!
author: Ishtar P.

description: Yes...breakfast burritos.  Perfect size and shape.   Yes my burrito was dripping from the oil of the cheese and the salsa.  It was cheesy and the eggs were freshly mixed with the potatoes right in front of me.  They also give you an option to go with a whole wheat tortilla.  Much better breakfast burrito that Rico Mex.  Poo on you nay sayers, SNOBS!
author: Ronjini M.

description: Food poisoning.  My coworker and I are both sick.   Someone else in the hall is too.  Not OK.
author: Amanda B.

description:
Just when I was about to give up hope...

Finally, a good Mexican joint in SOMA.  Fresh ingredients, tasty tortillas, and superb mole chicken.  Fast, fresh and, thankfully, not chipotle.
author: Sarah S.

description: Good a$$ veggie burritos that are affordably priced - I'm SUCH a fan of this place - I just wished they stayed open for dinner and opened a location in Oakland or Berkeley!
author: Always H.

description:
Great little hole in the wall.  Don't worry if the line is long- it moves fast.  I had the tacos and they were stuffed with meat.  I bought three, probably could have gotten away with two.

The "nacho fries" looked awesome but they were probably 8,000 calories so I passed.  Maybe next time.
author: Danny K.

description:
One of the best Mexican food I have tasted in a while. The service is fast, very courteous  and the food is flavorful, portions are very good and it is very reasonable. (Cash only has its advantages).
The Fajitas, Burritos, Salads and best of all the fresh made Salsa, I have not been disappointed any time I have been there.
author: Yoddha Y.

description: Let's get right to it: to me, a burrito tastes like a burrito no matter where it's from. More important to me is how easily it can be eaten. This was a loose, juicy, sloppy burrito -- I got my hands all messy and didn't even feel like finishing it.  With so many places nearby that offer better packaged burritos, I'm going to be picky about this.  +1 for accepting credit cards though.
author: Adam D.

description:
Disgusting! 

That's the only word you need to understand how bad this place is. I ordered 2 enchiladas one Carne Asada and one chicken. The meat was burnt, and very dry. 

The most amazing thing was they put my enchiladas in the MICROWAVE !! Anyone that rates this place 4 or 5 starts in a complete idiot, just for this reason. They nuke your food !! I also got a large side guacamole and they charge me for chips. Did they think I was going to eat a half pound of guacamole with a spoon? 

I will never go back to this place, and I will never recommend it. There are so many better Mexican restaurants in the area I don't understand how this place is still in business.
author: D. X.

description: In the downtown/SOMA area, Caramba is the best taqueria around. Come early enough on some days and horchata is on the house. I've been ordering carnitas however they can make it - on tacos, burritos, sopes, whatever. The breakfast burritos are super filling. The people working there are super nice too.
author: Vien T.

description:
They are great to hit up for breakfast. There have been countless times I have shown up for work, just leave my office and go there to pick up some Huevos Rancheros...it is really good.

Lunch and dinner, however, does not seem to be where the focus is. On my lunch break the last few times have been disappointing. I ordered a burrito one day and then a super burrito the next and there was virtually no difference in size between them. Super means more of something...an article of a superior quality, grade, size, etc. Well I guess it had more of a quality but lack of size minimized the enjoyment experience.

3 Stars.
author: James J.

description:
My lunch here at Caramba was a bit of an impulsive choice- I had originally come to the area with the intention of eating at the Chinese place a few doors down.  Unfortunately the Chinese place didn't seem all that appealing once we took a look at the steam table selections and we walked out without having a real clear idea of what we really wanted to eat.  Short on time, we saw Caramba and decided to get Mexican for lunch.

Caramba does have some interesting menu choices (fries in your burrito?) but we decided to go with the steak torta and an order of with al pastor.  Both items were okay- nothing particularly wrong with them but nothing spectacular either.  The steak torta came with a decent amount of grilled steak pieces (got a hint of some smokiness), as well as a liberal amount of refried beans, some pickled jalapeno slices, large slices of lettuce, some onion, and a small smudge of guacamole on a Dutch crunch roll.  Not sure that the Dutch crunch went all that great with the ingredients but at least the bread didn't get too soggy from the beans.  As for the nachos, we were disappointed that they placed the nachos in the microwave in order to melt the cheese.  The al pastor was just okay- the meat was chopped up in pretty small pieces so I wasn't really able to get a decent taste.  Their guacamole and sour cream were a little on the runny side, but other than that, its hard to mess up with nachos.

3 stars- not the best Mexican I've had by a long shot but it was decent.  I just wish they kept an eye on their salsa bar and the water containers- we were there not long after the lunch rush and the water was pretty much gone while I snagged one of the last two salsa containers.
author: Angela H.

description:
Gotta ding them. Today I went in for a burrito. The employees seemed to have a little trouble directing the flow of traffic and this before a huge line of people came in. (Perhaps that's what caused the backup.)

I ordered a Super burrito (which comes with guac and sour cream, but I requested no guac). The cashier called out for a Regular Burrito. I started up, remembered what I ordered, and waited.

The woman who made my burrito told the cashier it was for me, who then motioned it to me in the "oh, this is your order after all" sort of motion. I said I wanted a Super Burrito. Cue discussion. Burrito maker said I got a Regular one due to no guacamole. I glanced up at the sign and it says on their menu that a Super comes with BOTH sour cream and guacamole.

I said this to her and she said, "It's fine." Not that she put it in there, but the words, "it's fine." The gentleman who was involved with the traffic direction issue said to me, "That makes you feel really confident, doesn't it?" I agreed.

So I paid and got chips. I went back to work to find my suspicions were confirmed. No sour cream. I'm also docking a star for their super bland salsa. What happened? It used to be spicy! I even tried scooping up the salsa juice, but it was like eating chips with tomato pieces. 

It's a real pity, because I'm picky about my burritos and this place has chips consistently. And to be fair I was NOT charged for a Super Burrito. But I only said I didn't want guacamole, not sour cream. Clearly the burrito maker didn't want to admit her mistake.
author: AccioSoyMilk ..

description: My mom is probably the best chef there is....and I'm picky when it comes to mexican food bc I know how things are supposed to taste to me, and THIS place is right on the spot!! Breakfast burritos are almost the EXACT tasting as the one mom makes. And the salsa are the best also! Cheap food, filling food, and fast!
author: Norma M.
